PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island Preservation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Moreton Island is an invaluable natural resource for Queensland and the world and that mining on Moreton would gravely compromise its unique flora and fauna and its outstanding recreational archaeological and scientific values.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should urge the government to use its proven constitutional powers to halt sand mining on Moreton by supporting the Moreton Island Preservation Bill.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Joint Foreign Defence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains a satellite communication dish, that sends to the United States the information, gathered by the `joint high frequency stations' in Australia and New Zealand, indicating the position of the Soviet naval ships and submarines.
This information from Watsonia is combined with data from satellites and underwater sensors to calculate the location of the Soviet vessels with great accuracy.

2. This would make it possible for the US nuclear naval ships and submarines to destroy all nuclear Soviet naval ships and submarines, while the US nuclear submarines, naval ships and bombers launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack.
3. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
4. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should close the `Joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cooney (from 271 citizens) and Zakharov (from 90 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2 per cent discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 Oct 86 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term `extraordinary circumstances of the economy' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 Oct 86 to 1 July 87 so that pensions are restored to the 9 Oct 86 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Cooney (from 10 citizens), Kilgariff (from 18 citizens), Macklin (from 19 citizens) and Short (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread community concern about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia.
Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
1. Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia; and
2. Ban the import of cobalt-60 and caesium 137 and caesium 134 to be used to irradiate food products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Queensland State Elections
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Honourable members of the Senate assembled.

The petition of the undersigned in the State of Queensland showeth that the electoral system in Queensland, based on a 4 zonal weighted system, is an affront to democracy. The National Party under the leadership of Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen is always returned to Government with no opportunity for the voting public to bring about change.

Your petitioners point out that under the Queensland voting system the National Party at the State Elections on 1 November 1986 managed to achieve 55 per cent of the seats with only 39 per cent of the votes. This demonstrates that 61 per cent of Queenslanders do not want a National Party Government yet received one.

Your petitioners therefore earnestly pray that the Federal Government legislates as a matter of urgency to bring about a democratic system of voting in Queensland State elections based on the principle of one vote one value.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Any proposal to establish memorials to peace, the so-called Aboriginal War and anti-war activists and other left wing causes, at the Australian War Memorial in Canberra, would desecrate the Memorial as a fitting and solemn monument to those who served in Australia's Armed Forces and to those who died in defence of their country.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate acts to prevent anything which would desecrate the nation's memorial to Australia's former servicemen and women and war dead.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY ELECTION CAMPAIGN ADVERTISEMENT

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the disgracefully misleading advertisement inserted by the Australian Labor Party in newspapers on Saturday, which contained a quotation ascribed to a person who was described as `Westpac New York Chief', a currency trader in the Westpac Banking Corporation's New York office. I ask whether the Minister agrees with Bob White, the Managing Director of Westpac Banking Corporation, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: These comments were made not by `Westpac's New York Chief', as the advertisements claimed, but by one of our foreign exchange dealers. The comments were totally inconsistent with the kind of balanced judgment the public normally would expect from Westpac.

Is it a fact that the person concerned, who was quoted by the Labor Party in its advertisement, is on about the fourth level of seniority in the New York office of the bank? Does the Minister further agree with Mr White who, in advertisements to counter the deceptive Labor campaign, today has said that at this stage it would `be absurd to place any value on predictions about the post-election value of the Australian dollar'? Will the Minister apologise to the Australian people for this deception or is it the sort of campaign that we must expect from a Prime Minister who has already so blatantly broken his word by calling a July election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me refresh the minds of honourable senators about the series of incidents which took place. The morning following the announcement of the election a Mr Foley, I think his name was, who was described, I think, by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's AM program as a Westpac representative in New York made a statement that if a Howard-Bjelke-Petersen government were to be elected it would be disastrous for the dollar. That is the statement which was made. That statement inevitably, in the context of a forthcoming election, becomes currency within the election campaign. That sort of thing has been so under all governments of all political persuasions. Comments made about matters of public concern become matters of debate in an election arena. If the Opposition is too squeamish to face up to that, it will hear a little more of these unpalatable facts in the next few weeks.

ANSWER.PARA: I would not get too excited about this issue. I could keep this Senate for half an hour, telling it about the sorts of things that the Fraser Government did with advertisements of this kind and the sorts of allegations that it made. What about its 1977 dial a tax cut campaign? How long did the tax cuts last? They lasted three months after that Government was re-elected to power. The Opposition should not get too squeamish too early. It will have plenty of occasion for it later. Let me say in addition to the comments that have already been made that it is not just the gentleman who spoke on the ABC program the morning after the election was announced who has made those comments about the effects of the election of the former coalition. As Mr Sinclair says, after the election it will sit down and decide what policies it will implement. It is that sort of coalition. Other commentators have said exactly the same thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order--
—If this is getting too unpalatable for Senator Chaney--

—My point of order simply is that the Minister is clearly debating the question. He has rather sadly joined in this campaign of half truths and deception which the Government has undertaken. Mr President, I simply ask you to refer him to the question, which relates to the misdescription of this individual by the Labor Party in an advertisement which I understand it has now discontinued. I believe that the Minister should be brought back to the question and should stop the debate in which he is trying to obscure the issues about which people are concerned.
—There is no point of order, but the Minister should not debate the question. I call Senator Button.

—I do not want to debate the matter any further, if that is what I was alleged to be doing. The gentleman in question was, of course, described on the AM program on the morning in question as the chief currency trader for Westpac. It does not matter what his actual status is; he is a significant person in terms of the Westpac organisation and the New York market, and that is the important thing.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister agree that this person, who is somewhere down the fourth level of the bank, was described as Westpac's New York chief and does he agree that that is an inaccurate description?
—If we have to suffer no more marginal inaccuracies than that--
—This is going to be a good example.
—If the honourable senator wants me to go through his record again, I will start again; but I do not propose to do so when answering a supplementary question.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. In the light of the recent disturbing reports arising from the latest military offensive launched by the Sri Lankan authorities in the Jaffna peninsula, can the Acting Minister provide an assessment of the latest developments and the Government's reaction to them? Will the Government make its views known to the Sri Lankan Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very deeply concerned by the current Sri Lankan military offensive in the Jaffna peninsula. The offensive follows an escalation of the fighting between government forces and Tamil separatists after a number of terrorist attacks, as we all know, on civilians. The Australian Government deplores the escalation of hostilities in Sri Lanka. Tamil terrorists have been responsible for the deaths of many civilians. Government forces, particularly military aircraft, have, in turn, caused civilian deaths in their attacks on separatists' positions and the present fighting will inevitably lead to more civilian casualties.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has called repeatedly-it does so again now-for both sides to exercise restraint and begin negotiations to resolve the conflict peacefully. We have expressed our concern directly to the Sri Lankan Government on many occasions as well as in this chamber, international forums and, of course, in the House of Representatives. This week our High Commissioner repeated these concerns to the Sri Lankan Government in the context of the current offensive. Finally, all I can say is that the continuing bloodshed underlines the heavy responsibility which both sides share not to let the opportunity offered by the proposals which were put forward on 19 December for a peaceful solution slip away. The awful reality is that the alternative to that solution, the settlement as foreshadowed on 19 December, is a very grim one indeed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WHEAT SHIPMENTS TO FIJI: UNION BANS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing both the Minister for Primary Industry and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to the question which I asked him last week about the effect of Australian union bans on wheat shipments to Fiji when he indicated that he would check on the facts concerning the matter. I ask: Will the Minister now confirm that Fiji is facing serious grain shortages and that continuance of the bans is placing in jeopardy Australia's $10m wheat trade with that country? Is the Minister aware that a delegation of the Australian Wheat Board has asked the Government to intervene and a delegation is visiting Canberra today to press the point? In view of the failure of the Australian Council of Trade Unions to resolve this matter, I ask whether the Minister agrees with the Deputy Chairman of the Wheat Board, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: Now is the time for the Government to have this dispute resolved.
What action does the Government propose to take to bring this union action, which is in defiance of Government foreign policy, to an immediate end?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is known that the Government has urged quite forcefully that the wheat shipments should proceed. I understand that within the last 24 hours discussions have again taken place between members of the Government and the ACTU and that as a result of those discussions it is expected the matter will be resolved at a meeting this afternoon.

—I ask the Minister for Education: Has the Government made an estimate of the cost of adopting the proposal that all school students receive a basic grant, regardless of the type of school they attend, as proposed by the Opposition? Is it a policy which the Government would be prepared to adopt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen apparent undertakings by Mr Shack on behalf of the Liberal Party to increase funding to private schools. He has talked about giving all schools a basic grant, but it is hard to know what he means since all schools, government and non-government schools alike, receive a per capita grant from this Government. All schools receive a grant, but in the non-government sector those most in need receive a much larger grant than those with high incomes. However, if we try to work out what Mr Shack means, we get some interesting figures. If he means, for example, that those opposite will pay to the two categories of high income schools, those schools which have received no increases under this Government, the same grants as we paid the Catholic parish schools, the cost would be $66m. Since the Opposition is intent on reducing public expenditure to the tune of $8 billion we can only assume that that $66m for the top two categories of schools would have to come from the poorest schools in the non-government sector or from government schools.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The Minister's remarks are hypothetical and speculative. The Minister is called upon to speak within the terms of her portfolio responsibilities. Because what she is saying is hypothetical-in fact, it is rubbish-I submit that she should be asked to resume her seat.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister can answer the question in any way she sees fit. As long as she does not debate the matter, she is in order.

—Mr President, I am certainly not debating the question, as you are aware. It is a matter of interest to parents, students and teachers in government and non-government schools throughout Australia that these proposals are being floated, and people want to know what they mean. It is hard to work out what they mean since no dollar figures have been attached, but if, for example, all non-government schools were to be put into the highest category of funding-category 12-it would cost over $150m. If that is the proposal Mr Howard will tell us about when finally he gets around to a policy speech, we will be very interested to know at whose expense that $150m will be spent. There is also an undertaking to abolish the 12- category scheme and bring in three categories of school funding. Again, does that mean that schools that will be shifted from the nine categories that are not abolished into three categories would lose money or gain money? If they would lose money they are entitled to know that; if they would gain money, they should know how much and at whose expense.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also worth working out that the 12-category scheme was introduced after extensive consultation with the non-government sector and was welcomed by that sector. I think that Mr Shack and his colleagues on the other side of this chamber are having a great deal of difficulty getting a schools policy together since the policies of the Hawke Government have been so widely acceptable and successful. That reminds me that at Question Time on Friday I was asked by one honourable senator opposite to table the letter from the National Catholic Education Commission, which demonstrates that that major body, which has a policy of involvement with most non-government schools throughout Australia, is entirely in agreement with the Government's policy. I now table that letter for the interest of honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen the television advertisement sponsored by a range of organisations, including the National Farmers Federation, purporting to explain the implications of the now deferred Industrial Relations Bill? Does the Minister agree that the contents of the advertisement show considerable confusion about the relevant statute law and common law applying to industrial relations? Does the Minister intend to counteract this campaign with factual information about this extremely important area of law? If so, when would a response to the campaign be likely to start?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen twice the television advertisement referred to and I have been supplied with a copy of the text within it. I must say that I thought that the one I saw was sponsored entirely by the National Farmers Federation. I am open to correction, but that was my quick reading of it. It follows the same line as other misrepresentations of the provisions of the Industrial Relations Bill. It attempts to plant the lie that if the Bill as it was presented to the Parliament a couple of weeks ago were passed, it would no longer be possible for employers to invoke the secondary boycott provisions of sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act or to take common law action for damages. That is a lie. The Bill proposed to require that, prior to taking action under the Trade Practices Act and the common law, an employer would be required to take the dispute to the Industrial Court.

ANSWER.PARA: I also understand that the time frame which such an action would require would be shorter than the time frame that was actually recorded prior to the celebrated cases of Mudginberri and Dollar Sweets Co. Ltd being taken to the Federal Court. The National Farmers Federation has stopped a bit short of telling an outright lie. What it has done falls more into the category of a deliberate misrepresentation. In the relevant section the NFF said that the Government was very keen to alter the law so extensively that it would be virtually useless. That, of course, is untrue.

It should also be noted that on the question of common law there is an outstanding ambivalence in some quarters. Many people who argue that the employees' common law right to sue employers for negligence should be abolished also argue that no impediment or prior requirement should be imposed before an employer can take a common law action against employees. That is one of the many contradictions which the Federal Opposition and the ratbag Right generally in Australia need to resolve or to be called upon to resolve.

My final point is that I find it a bit disturbing, though personally not at all surprising, that the $10m-odd that the National Farmers Federation is reported to have collected ostensibly to launch a publicity or public relations campaign for the farming community is now quite obviously being misused by the NFF's President, McLachlan, as a personal political slush fund and is being spent and misused at the same time as McLachlan himself is touting around for a seat in this Parliament. It is not at all clear whether he intends to represent the National Party of New South Wales, the National Party of Queensland or the Liberal Party of Australia-that is, assuming that any of them would endorse him in a safe seat. It is not clear which of those fractions or factions he wishes to represent. However, it is perfectly clear that he no longer represents those whom he purports to represent, those same people that he has not represented for a very long time. I think that that is rather sad.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister provide a response to the last part of my question, that is, whether the Government is intending to counteract the campaign in any way at all with some factual information of its own on the issue?

—I am sorry, I was not trying to avoid that part of the question. So far as I know, the Government has no plans to counteract in any formal way the misinformation and outright lies. However, a number of people, including me, will be taking every opportunity that is available to expose the lies and set out the case as it really is. Finally, the argument against the Industrial Relations Bill should be put on its own merit. If the people who are opposing the Bill really have confidence in the soundness and validity of their arguments they should put them on merit and not resort to misrepresentation and outright lies.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen reports of the call by Professor Penington to scrap bulk billing-a call often used by the Opposition to justify its claim that it would abandon Medicare and bulk billing? Can the Minister explain to the Senate the consequences of scrapping Medicare and bulk billing, particularly as it would affect pensioners? Can he explain the evidence that shows there has been no overuse due to bulk billing, which fact the Opposition continues either to get wrong or to misrepresent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is generally recognised throughout Australia that the Federal Government's introduction of Medicare has brought equity and stability into the health and medical care system in a way which certainly was not evident when Mr Howard was Treasurer. Claims that doing away with bulk billing somehow would cut into the so-called overuse of medical services are completely unsupported by the facts. In the last full year of statistics available for the previous Government, Australians received some seven services per year, and under bulk billing they receive at the moment something like 6.67 services per year. It is quite clear that bulk billing bears no relationship whatsoever to the overservicing claims made by the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: The real point for Australian families to consider in relation to the Government's Medicare policy, as opposed to those proposals that emanate and occasionally erupt from the Opposition ranks, is that as far as one can judge-and this is based on figures compiled by the Treasury and the Department of Health, quite independent of any political influence-if the Opposition's health policy were put into effect the cost to ordinary Australian families would be in the region of $27 per week, regardless of the taxable income of the families concerned. In that situation, according to Treasury calculations, a family now paying the Medicare levy only would need to have an income of more than $110,000 a year to be better off under the Opposition's proposal. Even those families which currently have basic private health insurance would need an income of more than $72,000 a year to be better off. The tables that have been produced this morning by the Treasury and the Department of Health show very clearly that a family on average weekly earnings of $23,463 a year, or $450 a week, and currently paying the levy only would be more than $21 a week worse off-that is, it would pay an extra $1,100 a year in health costs-because there is a clear intention on the part of the Opposition to offload some $3 billion of health costs from the public to the private sector. That would have a very interesting effect, by the way, on the consumer price index. The transfer of $3 billion of health costs into the private sector would add some 3.65 percentage points to the consumer price index. So it is very clear from that that not only would there be a very severe impact on families if the Opposition's health policy ever were to be implemented--

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that those figures are crooked.

—Those figures are not crooked. They have been validated. I am very happy to incorporate in Hansard the three pages of figures produced by the Treasury and the Department of Health to substantiate those claims. I seek leave to incorporate those tables.

ADDITIONAL HEALTH COSTS UNDER OPPOSITION POLICY: FAMILIES WITH ONLY BASIC HOSPITAL INSURANCE (14 PER CENT OF FAMILIES)
ADDITIONAL HEALTH COSTS UNDER OPPOSITION POLICY: FAMILIES WITH TOP TABLE PRIVATE INSURANCE (36 PER CENT OF FAMILIES)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The fact is that the Australian Labor Party is very much wedded to the idea that at a time of recovering from some illness, major chronic ailment or traumatic car or industrial accident, one should not have terrible expenses added to family and household burdens. The payment of $27 a week required under the Opposition's policy for families to have the sort of health care they have now is absolutely intolerable and certainly will not be countenanced by this Government.
—I ask the Minister to table the document from which he has read, some of which he has incorporated in Hansard.
—I table the document.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I hope he can face up to it. I draw the Minister's attention to the Prime Minister's statement in February 1983, while he was Leader of the Opposition, that Prime Ministers must see out their terms of office in order to achieve rational business planning and public administration and rule out cynical political opportunism. Does the fact that Australia is now heading for its third Federal election in four years, and the Prime Minister's broken promises on capital gains tax, taxation levels, Medicare levies, fuel prices and interest rates, cause the Minister to have any doubt that Bob Hawke's word is a valuable Australian political commodity, as insisted by the Prime Minister last Wednesday?
—I am sure that the Prime Minister is a very valuable commodity. The honourable senator should just wait a few weeks and he will see.

—Has the Special Minister of State had an opportunity to discuss the Government's recently introduced crime package with the State police Ministers? If so, can the Minister advise the Senate of the results of such discussions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to tell the Senate that the Australian Police Ministers Council met on Friday, 22 May, in Hobart. It was a very successful meeting which was preceded by a meeting of the Intergovernmental Committee on the National Crime Authority. I must say, sitting around the table with Ministers representing various political forces within Australia, away from the glare of publicity and the confrontationist public stances that we sometimes adopt, we engaged in some very fruitful work on behalf of all Australian governments in combating organised crime in Australia. As I say, sitting around that table there were Ministers from all States and the Northern Territory in addition to me, representing the law enforcement agencies and the relevant portfolio of the Commonwealth Government.

ANSWER.PARA: At that meeting I reported on progress in regard to various elements of the crime package introduced by the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, in another place and to be debated here shortly. I will not canvass the elements of that debate, except to say that the package includes the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill, the Proceeds of Crime Bill, the Cash Transaction Reports Bill and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Bill. The fact is that this Government takes the view that it is not simply enough to beef up the Australian Federal Police, as we have done under a three-year program, which has increased its resources immeasurably and has increased the recruiting that the Federal Police has been able to undertake in order to meet the Government's objectives set out in the charter given to the Australian Federal Police in August 1985, which of course put the combating of drug trafficking at the top of its list of priorities. It is also not enough to give the National Crime Authority the resources that it has required which have enabled it, as I am sure all honourable senators will agree, to achieve very remarkable successes in its arrests and its bringing to trial of alleged major crime figures in recent months.

It was recognisable at that meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council that following the money trail is a very important part of any successful dealing with organised crime figures. Therefore, new offences such as money laundering, attempting to disguise the tainted character of money, are being introduced. Investigators are being given improved access to important financial records. But, more importantly-and I think this is what captured the attention of the Ministers around the table in Hobart-our legislation will provide for the forfeiture of assets of people convicted of serious offences such as narcotics dealings.

There is a strong sense in the community that restitution should be made by those persons who engage in these nefarious activities and accumulate assets as a result. No person should profit from his evildoing, according to an old common law maxim, and that principle is certainly to be incorporated in our attack on organised crime. In fact, we go so far as to say that, in this exceptional instance, the onus should be on the convicted criminal to demonstrate that his assets were lawfully acquired. I believe that the sense of justice in the community applauds this particular move. Of course, this leads to the fact, which I now report to the Senate, that the Australian Police Ministers Council unanimously passed a resolution-as I said, the Council comprised Ministers of various political persuasions-in the following terms:
To commend the Commonwealth on its initiatives in attacking the proceeds of crime and related matters.

I believe that completely unprompted commendation from the Police Ministers Council-mirrored, I might say, with good support for this package in the other place-indicates that this particular Government is succeeding in bringing forward a legislative framework to supplement the resources that are put into the Australian Federal Police and the National Crime Authority in order to succeed in its attack on organised crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services. Will the Minister confirm that the owner-drivers who operate Canberra hire cars have been threatened with a black ban if they do not join the Transport Workers Union of Australia? Does the Government condone this union blackmail? Will the Minister give an assurance that Canberra hire car drivers-who are owner-drivers and not employees-who decide to stand up against this union bullying will not be victimised by being denied government work?

—I think that I have heard some of the rumours that Senator Reid raised about there being a suggestion that officers of the Transport Workers Union have a certain view in relation not only to employees in the Commonwealth service but also those who are self-employed in the hire car business in Canberra. Neither the Minister nor the Department has any knowledge of these matters. However, I will refer the question to the Minister and see whether he wishes to respond further.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Is the Minister aware of the Leader of the Opposition's extraordinary claims that the 1 July tax cuts will be of no benefit to women in the community? Can the Minister comment on the real benefits that women in this community have gained through the Government's tax reform package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the extraordinarily dishonest and misleading claims which have been made by the Leader of the Opposition in relation to the effect of the tax cuts.

—On a point of order: I object to the description `dishonest' in relation to those claims. The question in fact was dishonest, but it mixed up several things, those being the total tax package and the 1 July tax cuts, which, the Leader of the Opposition said, would not benefit many millions of Australian taxpayers. I ask you, Mr President, to call the Minister to order and to insist that she answer the question, in terms of accuracy and not otherwise.
—There is no point of order.

—The facts are that the 1 July tax cuts represent a deferral of part of the Government's tax package, a deferral that higher income earners were asked to bear in the context of last year's Budget. The first round of these cuts which came into effect on 1 December was of the greatest advantage to low income earners, and particularly to women. The increase in the tax-free threshold from $4,595 to $5,100 assisted 130,000 people who became exempt from tax as a result of that increase. Women, who receive 77 per cent of social security payments, were the major beneficiaries of that tax reform. Some 40 per cent of women in the work force work part time and earn less than $10,000 per annum and, as a result of the tax reform package, they paid 13 per cent less tax. Women earning average weekly earnings received an additional $5.20 per week through tax relief. This, together with the effective flat tax cuts of $7.60 per week that this Government put into place in November 1984, has meant that women have seen substantial increases in disposable income as a result of amendments to the tax system.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, and very specifically-this relates to the issue that Senator Chaney tried to take a point of order about-the July arrangement has benefited many women. Mr Howard said that it would be of no benefit to women, and this just shows how the Liberal Party of Australia thinks. Mr Howard has conveniently forgotten the poverty trap measures; he has conveniently forgotten the many thousands of women in receipt of pensions and benefits who will be advantaged greatly by the poverty trap provisions which come into place on 1 July. This will mean that single and married pensioners will be able to earn an additional $10 and $20 respectively before their pension begins to reduce. It is quite clear that those people particularly, of whom a large majority are women, will benefit specifically from the poverty trap measures, which is a fact that has been overlooked completely and which has been neglected by Mr Howard, who only ever looks at the rich when he thinks about tax changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs both in that capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Territories. Is the Minister aware that the offer he is making to visiting medical officers in repatriation hospitals in his role as Minister for Veterans' Affairs would represent, if it were granted to doctors in Australian Capital Territory public hospitals, an annual cost of $6.9m, which is more than the doctors are prepared to settle for? Why is the Minister for Territories not prepared or not allowed to offer the Australian Capital Territory doctors the same amount of money for their services as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is prepared to offer repatriation doctors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The attitude that the Minister for Territories takes is entirely one for him to decide. I have a legislative obligation under the Repatriation Act to provide treatment in repatriation hospitals. Therefore, if the Australian community is of the view that there is an obligation on the part of governments and the community to recognise that fact, then I am entitled to avoid, and I accept the responsibility to avoid, the sort of situation that has developed in one or two of my repatriation hospitals as a result of a claim by the Australian Medical Association, on behalf of visiting medical officers, for the establishment of a scale of fees that is commensurate with the fees paid in the State hospital system, which vary from State to State.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said here in response to questions asked from time to time by both Opposition and Government senators, the Government's position is in unison with the positions of the State Ministers for Health. We have offered matching rates, whatever the State hospital system was prepared to offer, for sessional fees in the respective States. I have indicated that I am prepared to offer the same amount in respect of those hospitals regardless of the political complexion of the Minister for Health in each State. To that extent, I have the support of the National Party Minister for Health in Queensland, Mr Ahern, and the Liberal Party Minister for Health in Tasmania, Mr Groom, as well as the support of Dr Cornwall in respect of Daw Park in that State.

I believe that the Government's approach to this issue is fair and equitable, even though varying rates are paid to visiting medical officers in every State of the Commonwealth. In those circumstances, one can, in a certain philosophical sense, say that there should be a universal rate, but we do not have universal rates for service salaries or wages in respect of any awards throughout Australia. This is probably something that, in the fullness of time, will develop. In the current circumstances, I have negotiated with the Australian Medical Association a scale of fees that is higher in New South Wales than in Western Australia or South Australia, because the rates of pay in those States vary.

Of course, that is the approach that the Commonwealth is taking in respect of its obligations to veterans, who comprise a special group and who have treatment entitlements under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, which this Parliament approved. What the Minister for Territories does in respect of pay rates in the Australian Capital Territory is a matter outside my specific jurisdiction. I do not intend, and neither does the Government, to be in a bargaining or an option situation whereby one State would be treated differently from other States if there were to be a detrimental effect to veterans. In that regard I have the support of the Returned Services League. I refer to what Sir William Keys said to Dr Pickering from the Australian Medical Association. He said:
Now that an agreed compromise has been reached in all States except Queensland and South Australia, the RSL is disappointed that the AMA has resorted to industrial action in these States.
The RSL understands the doctors' wish to be fairly remunerated for their special skills and responsibilities.
He points out that during this time of economic restraint the Government cannot meet all the demands made upon it. I also have another statement, in which Dr Jennings, in South Australia, says:
I never thought I would see the bloody day come when doctors would turn away an 80-year-old veteran with a broken leg from a hospital.

He was referring to the fact that doctors in South Australia are refusing to treat veterans unless they are on emergency services. I also have a letter of commendation of the Minister and the Government, and condemnation of the doctors, from the Legacy Co-ordinating Council of Australia. The Government's attitude in respect of this very vexed problem, and very acute problem as it affects many thousands of veterans in our repatriation hospitals, is that it hopes that the doctors would not see salaries or incomes as being more important than looking after the medical health of veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of a supplementary question, Mr President, will the Minister confirm that, in effect, he is saying that the Government is prepared to pay doctors in New South Wales repatriation hospitals--
—We are prepared to give ex-servicemen a fair go; that is what we want to do. It is more than you will ever do.

—I know that the Minister has difficulty with his hearing; I am trying to make sure that he does hear the question. I ask the Minister: Is he saying to the Senate that the Government is prepared to pay repatriation doctors in New South Wales more than it is prepared to pay Australian Capital Territory doctors?
—It is a different system.
—It does not matter whether it is a different situation or not. The simple question is whether that is what the Minister is saying.
—What I am saying is that the Government's position is that it is prepared to match the rates paid to doctors in the State systems, and it is not prepared to depart from that.
—Are you prepared to pay politicians in New South Wales a different rate?
—Senator Walters is talking about it because she has a pecuniary interest in the matter, as her husband happens to be a doctor.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations as well as the Treasurer. I refer to an article in this morning's Australian by so-called commentator, David Potts, headed `Rising wages blow Government's Budget forecast cover'. Can the Minister provide any clarification on an assertion contained in the article by Mr Potts that wages have grown by 6.7 per cent in the year to the March quarter, as compared with a Budget forecast of 6.25 per cent?

—I have seen the article in question and it is wrong on a number of points, although I accept that Mr Potts got it wrong probably by accident whereas of course some other people, like McLachlan, the ratbag Right in general and the Liberal Party of Australia, generally get things wrong by design, as demonstrated by their advertisements and assertions. The accounts show that it is correct that for the March quarter wages, salaries and supplements grew by 6.7 per cent, but that is the aggregate payment and as such does not take into account the increased number of employees. In other words, the 6.7 per cent is not the figure for increases in wages, salaries and supplements per employee. It is derived partly from the increase in those payments per employee and partly from the growth in the number of employees. As we know, there has been extremely strong growth, particularly in recent months, in employment, maintaining the trend established by this Government since its first couple of months in office. Total employment has grown by more than 150,000 per year. The most recent figure that I can remember is that there are now 768,000 more people in jobs than there were in April 1983. That is in contrast, if I may say so, with the record of the previous Liberal Government. The recession over which Mr Howard presided destroyed in only one year a quarter of a million jobs, while in 4 1/2 years this Government has created an additional three-quarters of a million jobs. In particular, for the March quarter growth in earnings on a national accounts basis amounted to only half a per cent-a very major decline on figures recorded for the last quarter or two of 1986. More importantly perhaps, non-farm real unit labour costs fell by 1.1 per cent in the quarter. Real unit labour costs are not, of course, the same measure as nominal increases in wages and salaries. Real unit labour costs fell by 2.1 per cent over the year to the March quarter 1987, continuing the trend which once again has been evident throughout the lifetime of this Government. Real unit labour costs have fallen, again in stark contrast with the record of the previous Government in its final few years.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and concerns the recent military coup in Fiji. I ask: Did the Government have any prior knowledge of the likelihood of or pre-planning of the coup? Did the Government or any of its officials have any discussions with any other government, including the New Zealand Government, on this matter prior to the coup? In determining its current position on the Fiji situation, did the Government conclude that the Fijian Governor-General possessed the constitutional power to dissolve the Bavadra Government? If so, on what grounds was the dissolution legal? Finally, if the Government does not consider that the dissolution was constitutional, what is the current situation in Fiji and what government or authority does the Hawke Government recognise as either the de jure or de facto government of Fiji?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no prior knowledge in the Australian Government as to the circumstances which resulted in the coup or any knowledge of the coup itself. Nor, accordingly, was there any prior discussion with New Zealand about such course of events before they occurred. There has, of course, been a great deal of discussion since. As to the questions of the legal capacity of the Governor-General to dissolve the Parliament without the actual advice of Dr Bavadra, they are, as Senator Sir John Carrick should be aware from Press reports at least, matters which are being litigated now within the Fijian court system by Dr Bavadra and his Ministers. I do not think it would be at all appropriate under those circumstances for me to comment further, even if it were appropriate under Standing Orders to comment on a question involving so manifestly one of legal advice.

ANSWER.PARA: As we have acknowledged in public statements, there is an element of constitutional continuity, and certainly some greater element, in comparative terms, of constitutional propriety involved in the Governor-General exercising his authority as he did to declare a state of emergency and to accomplish certain results in the purported exercise of his gubernatorial power. However, whether that is such as to constitute a completely legal course of events in every sense of that term under the proper construction of the Fijian Constitution is something we reserve judgment on.

As to the question of Australia's recognition of the present Government in Fiji, vested as it is effectively in the person of the Governor-General, we have indicated that our position is one of non-recognition of the Fijian regime or the Fijian Government in the present circumstances. That is likely to remain the case for the foreseeable future, but beyond that I do not think it is appropriate for me to comment further. It is a matter, obviously, for ongoing review by the Government of Australia as the situation unfolds. Many situations could occur. There are many ways in which the situation could unravel in the days and weeks ahead, hopefully, possibly with the assistance of the mission that has been identified by the South Pacific Forum communique or maybe in some other way. In that still rapidly evolving situation I think it would be premature to state any final or decided view by the Government as to what is likely to happen in the future and when.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister a supplementary question: On what standing orders does he rest his reluctance to comment either because there is litigation in another country or because of the situation in this Parliament concerning commenting on another country? On what possible standing order does he rest?
—Whether it is an opinion about the constitutional law of Fiji or the tort law of outer Mongolia it is still a legal opinion, and Standing Orders prohibit me from offering one.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen a Press release from Senator Messner, dated 28 May, claiming that the car industry is being destroyed by the Government's harsh economic and taxation policies? What is the Minister's view on the health and future of the motor vehicle industry in Australia? How have Government policies contributed to its development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess we have been through this sort of question before in the Senate. Senator Messner, who is now the Opposition spokesman on industry, and the Opposition spokesman on Treasury matters, whose name temporarily eludes me, have always used the barometer of monthly market figures for the motor vehicle industry as a gauge to the basic health of the industry in this country. Senator Messner put out a Press release last week, which contained the following statement. In relation to the fringe benefits tax at this point he said:

ANSWER.PARA: At stake is the complete viability of a vibrant car industry . . . and further job losses for many thousands of workers.
Only when the fringe benefits tax is abolished and interest rates are significantly reduced will these disastrous trends be reversed.
And this will only eventuate under the policies of a Howard Government.

That is pretty cold comfort for the motor vehicle industry, if that is true by way of analysis, because it would have to face up to a very long and gloomy future before those things would be alleviated by a Howard government.

Senator Messner has been a shadow Minister long enough to know by now that the motor vehicle industry in this country is potentially more viable than it has been for many, many years. That is reflected in investment, export performance and so on. There is no industry in this country-the motor industry is no exception-of a significant kind which can go on satisfying a domestic market only, which is what Senator Messner sees as its role. This Opposition has learnt nothing in the last 10 years. If we relied on domestic market figures purely, no industry could have a very bright future.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all going broke.

—Let me give the Opposition a few facts which might help it to put out another Press release. It is true, as has been said on numerous occasions, that registrations of motor vehicles are down due to the effect of the devaluation. Very significant structural changes are occurring in the industry. Only on 29 May Nissan Motor Co. (Australia) Pty Ltd announced that it would spend a very significant sum of money in investment in Australia's local production over the next five years and would build a joint venture 4-cylinder car with Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd for export to Japan. The Nissan Motor Co. in Japan will make that investment. The conclusion of the Nissan Motor Company's Press release said:

ANSWER.PARA: This is a vote of confidence in the future of the Australian vehicle manufacturing industry.

One can also look at a company such as Ford which has invested $920m over the past four years to design and build a Falcon replacement and a new Laser-based sports car which will be exported to the United States of America. General Motors-Holden's is spending some $300m preparing the Commodore replacement, moving away from a reliance on overseas design expertise for its cars and using an Australian engine. Toyota Manufacturing Australia Ltd has spent $15m revamping its Melbourne manufacturing operations recently.

Whatever Senator Messner thinks, these are not the signs of an industry which threatens its workers with further job losses. The Nissan announcement has said that 800 more workers will be taken on by Nissan; there will not be a reduction in jobs. The job losses to which Senator Messner refers are stuck in his head from when the Opposition was in government because in the last year of the Fraser Government thousands of motor vehicle industry workers lost their jobs; they were thrown out in dollops of thousands. That has not happened since this Government has been in power, and it will not happen in either this or any other industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1987, which has been introduced in order to implement the international agreement for a new harmonised tariff. While the Opposition supports that legislation, I ask the Minister to indicate how many companies have expressed concern at significant cost disadvantages which will arise in instances where existing tariff rates will be raised as a result of restructuring to accommodate the harmonised system. Will the Minister further indicate whether the Government intends to respond positively to such representations that have been received and to seek to ensure that the cost structure of Australian industry is not unnecessarily increased by changes in tariff rates to be effected for administrative and tariff structural purposes rather than for protection of the industries concerned?

—I have seen no representations from companies in respect of accommodating the tariff adjustments which will occur with the introduction of tariff harmonisation. Representations may be floating around. Inevitably, if one makes a significant change to the tariff system, which tariff harmonisation does, there will be-as in all changes-winners and losers, checks and balances and so on. There will be some beneficiaries and some people who do not benefit. Maybe there will be complaints about that. If I get any such representations I will, of course, reply to them.

—I address my question to the Special Minister of State. In view of the Queensland Government's announced inquiry into the Four Corners allegations about organised crime, is the Minister aware of ongoing criticism that the terms of reference are inadequate to investigate fully the extent of corruption in Queensland? Will it be necessary for the National Crime Authority also to investigate these serious allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had drawn to my attention the terms of reference for an inquiry into many of the allegations which were raised on the Four Corners program concerning criminal activity and corruption of police forces in the jurisdiction of Queensland and in Brisbane in particular. Those terms of reference were announced by Mr Bill Gunn, the Deputy Premier, on 2 May. There has been universal reaction, certainly in the Queensland Press that I have been able to review, to the effect that the terms of reference are far too narrowly drawn as to both the time and the scope of the matters which should be inquired into by the commission of inquiry. The editorial of the Townsville Bulletin of Saturday, 30 May states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Queensland Government has done itself, the State's police force and the public a disservice by limiting the terms of reference of the commission of inquiry into allegations of police corruption.
There is no legitimate reason to limit the inquiry to just those five people-
who are named in the terms of reference-
nor to limit it to events of the past five years.

That is the point. It would be absurd to think that the matters raised and the allegations canvassed in that program erupted in the five years that this inquiry will look into. The scope should have been somewhat wider. If there is any saving grace in the setting up of this inquiry it lies in the appointment of Mr Fitzgerald, QC, to head it. Mr Fitzgerald, a very eminent Queen's Counsel, was formerly a judge of the Federal Court of Australia. There can be no suggestion whatsoever that he will bring anything but the highest integrity to the task that he has been given but, of course, his inquiry is to be conducted within those restricted terms of reference.

Mr Gunn indicated at the time of announcing the terms of reference that Mr Fitzgerald will be entitled to approach the Government at any time to seek an extension of the terms of reference. It is within that indication by Mr Gunn-and I am sure it is sincerely given-that the Queensland Government would react favourably to any such application by Mr Fitzgerald to extend the terms of reference that there is any sense of consolation at all when one looks at the setting up of this inquiry. Mr Fitzgerald, I suspect, will find the terms of reference somewhat restrictive. It is to be hoped that his application to the Queensland Government to seek an extension of those terms will receive due and proper publicity, as is the case with the National Crime Authority when it seeks a reference, so that we will know whether that Government is prepared to give the reference as required.

As for the National Crime Authority, it will be known to honourable senators that the Authority, using its general investigative powers, can investigate of its own volition and without seeking the approval of any government any relevant criminal activity of a serious kind, many of which were embraced by the Four Corners program. In respect of the Authority's coercive powers, it has a pre-existing reference from both the Commonwealth and Queensland governments which touches upon some of the matters raised in the Four Corners program. The Queensland inquiry will in no way displace the investigations being undertaken under that term of reference. The National Crime Authority will continue its own investigations and, I believe, may even talk to the inquiry once it is fully established. I think that with the activity of the Queensland Government, supplemented by the National Crime Authority, we now have a sufficient basis for the commencement of an unravelling of the allegations made on the Four Corners program. Insofar as the terms of reference prove insufficient, I am sure that Mr Fitzgerald will apply for an extension, and the National Crime Authority retains its plenary powers to carry out its own investigations.
