SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is continuing its debate on a package of five allied and two cognate Bills dealing with taxation. One of the principal features of this package is the introduction of a system of dividend imputation. Of some concern to the Senate must be the increased investigatory powers of the Commissioner of Taxation. These increased investigatory powers, and their extension to pay as you earn provisions, whilst they may on the surface appear to be quite reasonable, open avenues by which civil liberties of honest people may be infringed by over-zealous inspectors. The amendments, for example, will require taxpayers to give assistance to Australian Taxation Office investigators, rather than allowing just a right of access. This package of Bills will also give effect to a decision which was first announced in September 1985 and which has been significantly revised since that date.

SPEECH.PARA: In essence, these new arrangements will operate so that tax paid at the company level will, if certain provisions are met, be credited to the shareholder. While this appears superficially attractive, I believe there are a number of unsatisfactory features of this legislation. First of all, the Bills have the potential to cause significant shifts in investment patterns as shareholders relocate their interests into companies distributing more tax credits as dividends. In fact I believe that institutional borrowers and Commonwealth loan raising facilities will be the biggest losers. Extra burdens will also be placed on companies through increases in the company tax rate from 46 per cent to 49 per cent. The legislation will also cause additional administrative costs to companies.

The Bill also discriminates against companies which have shown the confidence to retain Australia as their base and have expanded their operations overseas in an attempt to win more overseas capital. So those companies that have shown this confidence to retain Australia as their base, and have expanded overseas, will, I believe, be disadvantaged by these proposals. These are the organisations that have learnt to operate successfully in a deregulated and extremely competitive environment. They will be penalised, and that is unfortunate. The interaction of the new imputation regulations with the foreign tax credits system will result in overseas investment becoming less desirable as far as Australian companies are concerned. I believe that this is another unfortunate result of the package. In fact, under the foreign tax credits system, companies with operations in the United Kingdom will have to pay tax at their rate of 35 per cent and, when they repatriate the profits from their off-shore operations to Australia, will be required to pay additional tax to cover the shortfall between the tax paid in the United Kingdom and the new Australian rate of 49 per cent. In this case, the extra tax would be 14 per cent. Under these regulations franking credits will accrue only on the 14 per cent paid in Australia and, therefore, the imputation credits flowing to shareholders will be considerably diminished.

Much of the benefits of the indexation of capital gains will be lost when the capital gains are distributed in full as a dividend. In other words, that dividend will not be fully franked. The Bill is full of inconsistencies in relation to its treatment of trusts in a loss situation compared with companies distributing losses through partnerships and other companies. The Bill perpetuates a tendency that has become obvious over the past five years to include increasingly complex formulae in our taxation laws. The laws should be simplified.

Claims about the benefits that will accrue to shareholders under imputation have been misleading in some cases. Just how tax-free the dividends will be will depend on the tax strategy of each individual company and their often complex domestic and international operations. In fact, the encouragement to pay more franked dividends and thus attract a greater shareholder interest could have the effect of draining new companies of capital. Such a situation will tend to favour established companies at the cost of new companies which require a cash flow, which is so important to be reinvested in order to establish themselves in the market. While this legislation has some redeeming features, it has a lot of inconsistencies and a lot of problems which will manifest themselves in years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my remarks to the part of Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 which deals with investment in the Australian film industry.
—Please don't.

—I know from the interjection by Senator Sanders that he is not in the least bit interested in the Australian film industry and would not want to assist the industry. That is perfectly understandable as far as Senator Sanders is concerned. Nevertheless, the provisions contained in this Bill introduce changes in the nature of films that may be excluded from the taxation concession regime by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. In particular, the amendments which are being made to section 124zaa of the principal Act allow the Minister now to exclude from the concessions those films that have `a significant non-Australian content'. Those are the actual words in the legislation. The amendment provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Where the Minister is satisfied that:
(a) a proposed film, when completed, will have a significant non-Australian content; or
(b) a film has a significant non-Australian content;
the Minister may treat the proposed film or film as not being a qualifying Australian film for the purposes of this Division.

The Minister has proposed these amendments as a result of the long running saga over a film entitled The Return of Captain Invincible. This film, which was a monumental box office failure, was made in Australia some years ago. In fact, this saga goes so far back that the Hon. Ian Wilson was the Minister who issued the preliminary certificate for this film to be commenced under the old 150/50 tax regime. The film was subsequently taken to the United States, which was always intended to be the principal market for distribution. In the United States it was cut substantially-virtually reconstructed. You will know, Mr Deputy President, as any senator with your knowledge of the film industry will know, that a film may be substantially altered after being shot depending on the way it is edited. This film was reconstructed in the United States. When the final version was presented for the Minister's completion certificate, a certificate was refused on the basis that the film was not the same sort of film as the Minister had originally intended.

The matter then proceeded through the courts. It was heard first by a single judge of the Federal Court, who held that there had been a failure on the part of the Minister to render natural justice to the film producers and that the Minister's decision to refuse the taxation concessions should be overturned. That matter went on appeal to the Full Bench of the Federal Court, which upheld the judgment of the judge in the first instance.

It is interesting that when I pressed the officers from the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment during the last Estimates committee hearings, which were concluded only a couple of weeks ago, it transpired that sums of money are still outstanding in relation to the legal costs of all parties following the conclusion of the legal proceedings in this case. In other words, due to the incompetence of the Department, in large part, and of the legal authorities of the Commonwealth, and despite the fact that this saga has been going on in the courts for more than four years and relates to an eminently forgettable film, although having Alan Arkin and Christopher Lee in its cast, this matter still continues.

Therefore, the Government has decided that it will change the Act so that the Minister will have the capacity to refuse to authorise the taxation concession by withholding his final certificate from a film if it has what the second reading speech describes as a significant non-Australian content. The second reading speech states, in part:

The Government does not believe that the tax concessions for investments in Australian films should be available where creative control is in non-Australian hands, even though the shooting of the film and other activities may take place in Australia.

That is a particularly curious addition to the Act. When one considers that in many instances the reconstruction of a film by editors that takes place outside Australia may be quite integral to the financial viability of the project, it is an unfortunate addition to the Act. Briefly, some of the most successful Australian films, such as the Mad Max films, have undergone reconstruction and editing to make them more suitable for particular markets. For instance, the Japanese versions of those films have differed in significant measure from the films shown in Australia. Major changes have been made, and such changes are always made, in terms of the dubbing of scripts in the United States. In fact, many Australian films are released in the United States with a voice-over track dubbed by Americans because, allegedly, Americans have some difficulty with Australian accents in some Australian films.

We know it was indicated that the film Malcolm, which was an outstanding success in Australia, would not be released in Singapore unless it was reconstructed with an ending different from that shown in the Australian film in order to comply with the moral standards of Singapore, where it must be asserted in all instances that crime does not pay. The end moral of the film Malcolm was that certain types of crime do pay and, indeed, under certain circumstances ought to pay. Therefore, if that film was to be shown in Singapore it had to be reconstructed.

It is very difficult to expect Australian films to compete on international markets if from time to time they must be altered for different foreign markets to increase their financial viability and if the Minister subsequently says: `I think it has gone too far. I will exercise my judgment as to what constitutes significant non-Australian content'. There are really no sound definitions in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 of what constitutes significant non-Australian content. It therefore puts the Minister in a position of making, in essence, a judgment, which is not a judgment of fact but one of opinion. As I have indicated, the Minister in his second reading speech concedes that the shooting of a film and other activities may take place in Australia but if there is some degree of creative control in non-Australian hands then the Minister may exercise a judgment not to allow the taxation concession to be paid. I think that that is an unfortunate development in terms of Government financial support for the Australian film industry. This is not to say that some of the other steps taken by the Government to provide financial support for the film industry have not been without their critics. As you would know, Mr Deputy President, the original regime introduced by Mr Ellicott when he was the Minister for Home Affairs in the time of the Fraser Government provided for a taxation concession of 150 per cent of the investment and for a 50 per cent relief on the profits made from the film. That has been gradually whittled down from 150-50 initially to 133-33 and subsequently by this Government to 120-20. In itself that occasioned a fair amount of criticism.

A number of people have drawn attention to the fact that this now increases the necessity for films to achieve pre-sale in order to establish the sort of viability which will attract investors. It is certainly true that some time ago criticism was made that this might have an adverse impact on the quality of Australian films that are made. I did not support that point of view at any stage. Indeed, there are grounds for saying that a film which requires a greater degree of pre-sale is more likely to be a film of quality and one made by people with a proven capacity and that, as a result, there would be a necessity for young film makers to rely a great deal more on the support which they get from the Australian Film Commission through its Creative Development Branch. I will say something about further funding for the film industry in Australia later.

Nevertheless, I think that there are trade-offs in this matter. The lower level of tax write-off has the capacity to increase the quality of Australian films which then in fact do continue to be made. The one thing that I regret is that I think that it will increase the pressure to make films for television rather than for the cinema, and I think that that is an unfortunate development within the industry. However, it was indicated in the May 1986 edition of Encore that at that stage there was still a large amount of money around in terms of potential investment in the film industry, even under the new regime and that in fact what was absent was the number of good scripts and good technicians-not on the creative side but on the technical side-to make quality Australian films.

The effect of the Government's changes to the film industry as far as taxation is concerned can be put in these terms, namely, that the effect of the change is really to increase an investor's margin of risk after tax from 20 per cent to 28 per cent, assuming a 60 per cent marginal tax rate and a 100 per cent eligibility. In practice the level of pre-tax return required to breach the after-tax margin of risk will be greater because a proportion of the bridging return will now be taxable. The prima facie effect of the Government's reductions is to put upwards pressure on pre-sale requirements, as I have already said. This will lead to a downturn in the level of fund raising to the extent that such pre-sale requirements are unable to be met and ultimately to a downturn in production activity.

The changes to the tax regime, both in terms of the level of personal tax cuts and of the reduction of support for the industry as a whole, have led the Australian Film Commission to develop an alternative. In a paper entitled, `Film Assistance-Future Options', prepared by David Court on behalf of the Australian Film Commission, a series of new proposals has been advanced for the establishment of a loan corporation which will finance films through direct loans made by the Australian Film Commission rather than by the use of the taxation system. It is interesting to note that although this proposal has been around for some time the Government is only now considering it seriously. An article which appeared in today's edition of the Australian quotes Mr Kim Williams, the Chief Executive of the Australian Film Commission, as calling for `the immediate establishment of what he would call the Australian Loan Corporation to ensure that film and television production did not fall to unacceptable levels in the new financial year'. The article reads in part:

Speaking on the Channel Ten network's Business Week program, Mr Williams said that film funding next year would fall to a `most worrying level' of just $50m, from between $130m and $150m this year, because of the combined effect of the lower tax deduction and the falls in marginal income tax rates.

Investment in the Australian film industry is still extremely worthwhile. The film industry continues to make one of the most significant contributions to creative endeavour in this country. It is a most important and integral part of the projection of Australia overseas. The success of Australian films is very much related to the success the tourism industry has had in attracting tourists and revenue to Australia. I therefore hope that the Government will be able to indicate fairly promptly its response to the Australian Film Commission. As somebody on this side of the chamber who has some very close associations with the development of the film industry I would be, in general, very keen to support-and for the next Liberal Government to support-the proposals put forward by the Film Commission in its discussion paper. I do not agree with all of the specifics put forward, either in the discussion paper or in the supplementary paper on the finance corporation model which the Film Commission released in January this year. Nevertheless, the general thrust of its suggestions should be adopted and borne in mind.

I want to say something very briefly about one other minor matter. I will delay the Senate for only a couple of minutes to conclude my remarks. People will have noticed the Government's claims as to the rationale for the double dissolution election. It has resurrected arguments about the Australia Card and its impact on tax, tax evasion and tax fraud. We will have the opportunity in the electorate to discuss this matter at considerable length. People will have seen the advertisements already placed by the Australian Labor Party in the newspapers claiming that the Australia Card is important for the proper administration of the taxation system. The Government is anxious to ensure that there is not full public discussion on this matter. I was in Orange over the weekend. The local newspaper in the area, the Western Advocate, carried a couple of letters in an edition some weeks ago dealing with the Australia Card, the identity card, and the comments made about it by the Labor Party. Mr Brian Davis, Vice-President of the State branch of the Australian Small Business Association, had a letter published in the Western Advocate on 28 January 1987, in which he said, in part:
Socialist governments also try and give a plausible excuse-usually a red herring and not associated with the real issue-in order to justify their actions and to not stir up the masses too much.

The Hawke socialist party and, particularly our local member, Mr David Simmons, have kept to the socialist tradition and are trying to sell the population hard on their promise that the Australia card will only be used to control tax evasion and social security fraud and for no other purpose.
To trust a promise of this Federal Government or of our local member who is indeed a socialist in the true sense of the word is naive to the extreme . . .

It is certainly true that one of the arguments the Labor Party has put forward is that the Australia Card will be used only for certain purposes, that it will not be open-ended and that it will be an effective tool against taxation fraud. We know that all of those arguments are false. We know that the Australia Card will not be an effective tool against taxation fraud. Senator Haines, who was one of the members who sat with me and other senators on the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, knows that that is correct.

We know that the card is an open-ended invitation to a great deal of misuse. It is curious, therefore, that attempts are being made to suppress public debate on this matter. As I understand it, Mr Davis is being sued by Mr Simmons, the local member for what he has said about this matter in an attempt to suppress public debate on an issue which the Government has sought to make absolutely essential to the election campaign on which it has hinged the double dissolution, that is, the rejection by this chamber twice of the Australia Card legislation. It is already running advertisements in the newspapers which are not correct. Claims being made about the Australia Card in those advertisements are not correct. They should be refuted in public debate during the campaign. It is a pity that members of the Australian Labor Party are prepared to resort to the courts to prevent full public discussion of the significant issues taking place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The clutch of Bills that we are debating today, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987, the Income Tax (Franking Deficit) Bill 1987, the Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1987, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill 1987, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1987, and the Income Tax Amendment Bill 1986, represent the latest instalment of the Government's continuing tax reform program which, in principle, the Australian Democrats have supported, although only after securing some notable amendments. The tax reform program has closed off many of the lurks and perks that, it would appear from some of the contributions in this place in recent days and from some of the statements made outside the House, the Liberal Party would want to see preserved, perks that have advantaged a very privileged sector of the population at the expense of ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: A classic example is the capital gains tax legislation, which the Liberal Party opposed when it was introduced in this place, despite the fact that it is a considerably weaker capital gains tax than that which applies in the United States and which, apparently, the Liberal Party still opposes to the extent of promising to repeal the legislation. The capital gains tax which the Government introduced, and which we supported because it is part and always has been part of Democrat tax policy, has brought in about $1 billion worth of revenue. That amount of revenue is desperately needed to fund government programs that are beneficial to all Australians and not just to those people who are already well off-the sorts of programs that apparently appeal to the Liberal Party in particular. Without the capital gains tax, for example, the feverish activity on the Australian stock market recently, which has resulted in something like $80,000m being added to the value of Australian stocks, would have largely escaped tax.

I cannot understand why we should subscribe to an argument that money earned from capital which is risked should be exempt from tax when we do not put that same argument with regard to income earned when one's health or indeed one's life is risked, as often happens with people who work down mines and on oil rigs, fly planes and so on. We never hear that argument then, and I cannot see why capital should be regarded as so much more sacrosanct than life or health that the money earned from it when it is risked ought to be exempt from taxation.

The major Bill in this package, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987, or what is generally known around this place at least as the imputation legislation, introduces a full imputation system of company taxation. That legislation will not only impose a fairer system of taxation; it will also increase the attractiveness of equity financing, as distinct from debt financing, of company activities in Australia. The recent increased reliance on debt financing has resulted not only in a dangerous escalation of company gearing but also in a great leakage of revenue which, as I said earlier, is desperately needed in this country if we are to provide the sorts of services that over 16 million Australians of all ages in all walks of life and in all socio-economic sectors need and deserve.

The large borrowings of overseas funds for the financing of company activity, particularly negatively geared takeovers, which I have mentioned before almost ad nauseam in this place, have resulted in a fall in taxable company income as a result of debt being claimed as a business expense without the interest payments on those borrowings bearing Australian tax other than withholding tax. The benefit that people such as John Elliott and other sharp takeover players have derived from the tax deductibility of debt financing has not flowed through to the general population. I have seen no evidence from anywhere to suggest that the spate of negatively geared takeovers that has occurred over the past few years has resulted in the type of restructuring of our productive base which is necessary if we are to trade our way out of the present economic crisis. Those negatively geared takeovers in the main are highly non-productive. There is rarely any increase in employment as a result, and often quite the reverse. To the best of my knowledge there has not been any additional gain in export markets as a consequence of any of these takeovers. Yet the Government is quite prepared to sit back and allow these takeovers to be funded-underwritten, if you like-by the taxpayer through negative gearing.

The Democrats have been pressuring the Government for some time now to place a limit on the deductibility of debt in the case of negatively geared takeovers. We have been told by the Government that such a technically difficult amendment is out of the question. I would have thought that anyone looking through the hundreds of pages of recent tax legislation would be forced to believe that technical difficulty had not unduly concerned the Government in other areas of tax reform. In fact, Senator Short, in his contribution to the debate last week, commented on the extraordinary complexity of tax legislation that has been introduced into this country in recent years. That includes the clutch of Bills that we have before us. I fail to see how a government can argue that simple technical difficulty is any justification for allowing the sort of negative gearing of which we have seen so much lately to continue.

We are also told that a limit on negatively geared takeovers would be an interference with the market-as if the Government does not already interfere with the market. In fact, the amendment brought in by Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5), to treat short term redeemable preference shares as a debt, not equity, is an interference with the market. It removes an instrument by which companies in a debt position are able to achieve a tax benefit equal to the benefit available to companies in a profit position. It is amazing that this myth of deregulation and the so-called free market services, despite the clearly demonstrable fact that an advanced economy can operate only with a complex structure of government regulations. It seems to me that what contributes most to this debate is whether the speaker approves of the regulations. The Australian Democrats will be supporting this package of Bills, although we have significant reservations about some aspects of the imputation system and will be moving amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5). The reservations that we have about the imputation legislation relate in particular to certain anomalies which arise through the interaction of this legislation with other aspects of the taxation system.

I want to spend a few moments canvassing some of those anomalies. The major one relates to the capital gains tax introduced in Australia some time ago to tax real capital gain. It is important when we are talking about the anomaly within the imputation legislation that we understand that the capital gains tax that was introduced in Australia taxes real capital gains and not nominal gains. In other words, if a person buys an asset for $100-to keep the figures fairly simple, I will use that as an example-and after five years, during which time inflation has been running at around 10 per cent a year, sells that asset for around $160, an increase having accumulated through inflation, there is no liability to pay capital gains tax. The profit of around $60 is not really profit but simply the result of inflation-a nominal gain, not a real gain.

If that process had been undertaken by a company rather than a natural person, the company also would not pay capital gains tax. If, however, the company distributed the nominal gain-the $60 or thereabouts-to its shareholders as a dividend, a problem would arise. Because the company had paid no tax on that increase over the previous five years because it was not really income and therefore was not subjected to tax, the dividend distributed to shareholders would carry no tax credits and would be fully taxable in the hands of the shareholder, providing essentially a revenue windfall for the Government. I can only hope that this is what is becoming known around this place as an unintended consequence, because it is a crazy result. I think it is a grossly unfair result. It is unfair, firstly because it imposes a tax in a situation where there has been no real increase in the relevant taxpayers' wealth although, as we are all aware, there has been a nominal increase. Secondly, it runs counter to the indexation principle adopted in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Thirdly, it encourages the ownership of assets by individuals rather than companies, despite the fact that ownership of productive assets and thus the carrying on of business by companies is more conducive to economic growth than the ownership of those assets and the carrying on of those businesses by individuals.

Similar anomalies arise in the case of foreign tax credits and depreciation provisions. If, for example, an individual has foreign sourced income on which 49 per cent tax has been paid overseas, under the foreign tax credits legislation no Australian tax is due. If a company receives foreign sourced income on which 49 per cent tax has been paid overseas, the company is not liable, for the same reason, to pay any Australian tax. The foreign tax credit legislation gives a credit for all foreign tax paid. If, however, the company distributes that income to its shareholders by dividend that dividend will bear full Australian tax. I am not suggesting that a tax credit should attach to the nominal capital gain distributed to shareholders nor, as Senator Short seemed to suggest last week, should it attach to the foreign sourced income distributed to shareholders. There should be no tax credit because no Australian tax has been paid. However, to apply full tax to dividends is both unfair and anomalous. It also creates a situation in which, in an effort to avoid the anomalies, artificial arrangements are bound to result. I would have thought that we have seen enough of that in this country to try to avoid it at all costs. As I have said, I hope that this measure is one of the famous unintended consequences mentioned recently by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in relation to other tax matters and that the Government will see fit to do something about it.

The effective imputation on depreciation is, effectively, to nullify the incentive provided by various accelerated depreciation provisions in other taxation legislation. While I acknowledge that in the United States measures such as accelerated depreciation allowances have been abandoned, they have been abandoned only because the top marginal tax rate has been dropped as an offsetting mechanism. Again we are concerned about that element creeping into this legislation. Therefore, the Australian Democrats are concerned that the package of imputation Bills before us fails to address the anomalies to which I have referred and it also fails to contain the anti-avoidance provisions which will have to follow the repeal of Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It is no answer to say that the drafting of a mechanism to deal with the anomalies would be difficult. We have suggested to the Treasurer's office one mechanism for getting around the capital gains anomaly which involves the creation of an exempt dividend account. If, for some reason, that solution is not viable, I would appreciate an explanation from the Minister as to why it is not viable or an indication from him that the anomalies to which I have referred will be addressed by the Government in the near future.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1986 was debated before it was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and at that time I outlined the Democrats' position on that legislation. The majority of the Committee reported that the legislation, insofar as it referred to short term financing arrangements, did not contain any provisions which should not have been reasonably anticipated from the Treasurer's announcement of 7 April 1986. There is increasing concern in many quarters-including the Democrats and the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills-about this Government's increasing tendency to legislate by Press release. It is neither fair to the Parliament nor fair to the people who are being dealt with under the proposed legislation. I ask the Government, particularly in taxing matters, to consider seriously ceasing that operation or, at the very least, keeping the legislation, when it is introduced, within the realms of what was suggested in the Press release.

I do not agree that in this case the legislation, as drafted, is necessarily wider than the terms of that announcement, and those affected by the announcement were entitled to rely on its strict wording. The comment I made a moment ago seems to be the minimum requirement placed on government if it is going to proceed with the exercise of legislating by ministerial announcement. The Democrats will be moving an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment (No. 5) Bill and that amendment will be circulated as soon as possible. Essentially the amendment will limit the provisions of this Bill which deal with short term financing arrangements to the effect signalled by the Treasurer's announcement of 7 April 1986. As I have said, that amendment will be circulated as quickly as possible and certainly before we reach the Committee stage.

I now turn to the amendment moved last week by Senator Short on behalf of the Opposition. That amendment was merely an attachment to the second reading motion of the package of legislation which does not affect the contents of the legislation in any way, but it is worth while looking at it from the point of view of what it says about the Opposition's attitude to tax laws. It is a long amendment which makes some six points with regard to, presumably, the Opposition's philosophy on tax. The first point condemns the Hawke Labor Government for raising the company tax rate from 46 per cent to 49 per cent at a time when company tax rates around the world are being lowered. I would certainly agree with that statement if there were any evidence at all that the companies concerned were paying anything like the 46 cents in the dollar which, up until now, has been the company tax rate.

Statex research studies and tables in a recent Business Review Weekly indicate that tax paid, as a percentage of pre-tax profit, is nothing like 46c in the dollar. In most cases it is nothing like even the lowest marginal tax rate that individual PAYE taxpayers contribute to Consolidated Revenue. For example, tax as a percentage of pre-tax profit paid by News Corp. Ltd was 15.42 per cent, Brierley 13.13 per cent, Elders IXL Limited 10.35 per cent, the Bell Group Ltd 27.04 per cent, Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd 25.87 per cent and David Jones Limited 10.75 per cent. I would have thought that most individuals in the community would dearly love to be able to pay those levels of taxation but, of course, they cannot pay them because they do not have the sorts of deductions that will get their marginal tax rate down to anything like that level. Faced with that situation the Government has two choices. It can either increase tax in order to increase revenue or it can decrease tax and remove-as has the United States-deductions such as accelerated depreciation allowance. The Government chose the first course presumably because it still believes that in a country such as Australia some industries justifiably benefit from allowances such as the accelerated depreciation allowance.

The second part of the amendment notes that the Government's so-called tax reform proposals have imposed an additional tax burden on business in excess of $2 billion. That is hardly surprising, given the low levels of tax many companies have been able to get away with paying in the past and, as a consequence of these proposals, are not able to get away with now. Taxes such as the capital gains tax are a significant improvement in this area. The third part of the amendment notes that these new business taxes have been imposed at a time when the level of business investment in this country has fallen to an appallingly low level and there is a rising tide of bankruptcies. Sometimes I wonder whether business investment in this country has fallen because the Government is gradually taking away a lot of the unnecessary corporate welfare that business has operated on in the past, and that companies are not prepared to invest unless they are almost 100 per cent guaranteed of success in that area-in which case they can hardly claim that they are risking anything, much less their capital.

The fourth part of the motion notes with concern that the interaction of the proposals in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987 with the foreign tax credit system and the new capital gains tax imposes a tax disadvantage on companies and on their shareholders. I think I addressed that matter adequately enough in the bulk of my speech without having to refer to it again, except to repeat that I wonder why companies think that they, and only they, should be exempt from paying tax at the level at which ordinary individuals are expected to pay it. The fifth part of the amendment notes:
. . . the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987 also contains unnecessarily complex administrative and compliance procedures for companies.
That is linked with paragraph (6) which calls on the Government:
. . . to restore the incentive to invest by pursuing a more balanced economic policy and reducing the taxation and administrative burden on business.

I would argue that one of the reasons why this Bill is so complex is that while there are smart lawyers and accountants who are able to rip off the system, to find loopholes, to manipulate the law to suit themselves, the Government has little choice but to close those loopholes. The only way to do that is to introduce some extremely complex amendments, unless one is to scrap the entire taxation system and move towards something which it appears the Premier of Queensland has been suggesting, a 25 per cent flat tax-if by that he means that everybody, individual or company, pays 25 per cent of every dollar they earn from $1 and is not entitled to any deductions at all. If that occurs there will be some companies which will pay a fair amount of tax for the first time in their lives, but somehow I doubt that that is what the Queensland Premier means.

I believe the Queensland Premier is talking of a 25 per cent top rate for everybody, in which case some low income earners on, say, less than $23,000 a year will find themselves paying more tax each year than they are paying now; and those companies which are paying, as is Elders IXL Ltd, for example, 10.35c in the dollar, when nominal company tax is 46c in the dollar, will be paying almost half that if the Bjelke-Petersen proposal comes into operation. Those people in the community who are lulled by the simplicity of the Bjelke-Petersen argument into believing that support for the Bjelke-Petersen party will make them better off should think again. They should start by sitting down with last year's tax return and working out how much they did pay.

As for the last part of the amendment, that calls upon the Government to restore incentive to invest by pursuing a more balanced economic policy and reducing the taxation and administration burden on business. I would say that basically we would agree with that. But the problem is historically based because of the high rates of protection that have existed in this country for decades, which have led to a welfare mentality in the business community far greater than the welfare mentality in the rest of the community. There are some big, wealthy companies which expect non-means-tested, non-repayable subsidies to shore up some of their subsidiary companies, while they continue to make large profits which, because of the many deductions that now exist in the taxation system, they are able to reduce to the extent where essentially they are paying considerably less tax, and thus making considerably less contribution to Consolidated Revenue than do the vast bulk of individual salary and wage earners. That is an inequity that should be faced by this Government and by whichever government is able to get itself into power after the election of 11 July.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support the Liberal Party's amendment to the second reading motion on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill and allied Bills. I wish to deal with the imputation aspects of this legislation, which I shall try to explain a little to some of my colleagues who may not know all about it. Currently company dividends are distributed to shareholders and are taxed twice. They are taxed first at the company rate of 46c in the dollar, and then are taxed in the shareholder's hands where the shareholder has to pay tax on the dividend. If the shareholder happens to be in the top marginal rate bracket, he therefore pays 60c in the dollar on top of the company tax that has already been paid. The result is that the shareholder in respect of the original dividend dollar receives only 21.6c. Clearly that is an unreasonable amount to be taxed.

SPEECH.PARA: The imputation mechanism in respect of the initial dollar divided will impose tax at 49c in the dollar and there will be no further tax. The shareholder will be paying a tax rate of 49c rather than the current 78.4 per cent of the dollar that he or she pays at the moment. Because the tax paid by the company will be imputed, this means that each dividend will have a tax credit attached or attributed to it, which will be called the franked dividend. As a franked letter has the postage prepaid, so a franked dividend has the tax paid. Therefore, when a shareholder gets his dividend, all the tax has already been paid at the top rate of 49c. As of I July that will be the highest personal rate of tax.

This all sounds very good, but there are elements that need to be closely examined. I shall elaborate on a few of those elements. Company taxes will be raised just from 46c to 49c in the dollar. This is at a time when companies in Australia are being taxed at a rate higher than companies are taxed in the rest of the world where tax rates are falling. The cost to business in Australia will be $475m. The result will be that some companies will have less profits to distribute in the first place. This is an inconsistent approach involving the raising of company taxes from 46c to 49c in the dollar. Therefore, this legislation, in our opinion, will benefit only a small number of shareholders because only some 15 per cent of shareholders are private individuals. The legislation therefore will disadvantage 85 per cent of all shareholders because of the rise in company tax. Even the 15 per cent who will be receiving the major benefit from the imputed or franked dividend will be receiving a quite small dividend.

If these shareholders are paying less than 49c in the dollar and are earning more than $35,000 a year after 1 July, the imputation credits they will receive with dividends will exceed the tax they would need to pay on the franked amount of the dividends. This excess rebate can now be offset against other income, including capital gains, which is as it should be. However, if for some reason a shareholder does not have enough other income against which to offset the excess rebate, he must forfeit it. In other words, he cannot get a refund and cannot offset it against his Medicare levy. This legislation is therefore not a genuine 100 per cent imputation package. Businesses that suffer a loss will lose the advantage of dividend income. Low income earners will be the people who are most adversely affected by having to forfeit the benefit of the excess rebate, and they should at least be allowed to carry forward the unused portion of the franking rebate. The big winners from this legislation will be the people who depend on dividend income as a large proportion of total income. It is evident that the ramifications of this imputation legislation will be anything but simple.

To sum up, the National Party believes that the legislation has many good points and that this is a step forward in an attempt to eliminate double taxation. However, there is too much of the Clayton's image about it, because despite popular belief it will benefit only a minority. It half-heartedly attempts to restore tax equity in the shareholder-dividend area. It is riddled with anomalies, some of which are quite blatantly wrong in their impact. A mass of changes and refinements to this legislation will be necessary in the future. As a colleague in the House of Representatives, the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), said:
Imputation Paul Keating-style is like a shiny red apple that when bitten open reveals not just a grub but half a grub and we are left lamenting as to what could have been.
In summary, the National Party supports the amendment moved by the Liberal spokesman, Senator Short.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment (Company Distributions) Bill 1987 and a number of other taxation measures brought down by the Government, the net effect of which will be to introduce the imputation initiative announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) many months ago as part of the original taxation package. I congratulate the Government on this part of the tax package which represents very significant reforms. I would go along with the Treasurer when he claims that the imputation legislation is the most significant taxation reform in the post-war years. There is a certain amount of justification for that claim in the sense that with imputation ordinary Australians will now be attracted to buying shares in Australian public companies. Before, only the very wealthy could buy shares in Australian public companies because shareholders in the highest tax bracket were being taxed effectively at 78.4 per cent. In other words, the wealthy bought shares in Australian companies only for speculative reasons, in the hope that a company would be taken over and the shares would suddenly escalate. No ordinary Australian would buy shares in public companies in this country with the idea of holding those shares as a reasonable investment in the long term. This imputation legislation is a dramatic reform. I give all credit to the Government for introducing it.

SPEECH.PARA: Many Australians do not realise that dividends from shares in public companies are tax free in the hands of companies. In other words, this imputation legislation does not really affect the big shareholders in Australia-other public companies, the takeover merchants or institutions-because they are not subjected to double taxation on company dividends. Dividends from public companies in the hands of other companies are tax free, but not so for the ordinary Australian. This legislation will have the effect of making the purchase of shares in public companies attractive to ordinary Australians. That means that the capital base from now on will be shared much more broadly; ordinary Australians now will have an incentive to acquire a stake in the prosperity of this country. I congratulate the Government that at the eleventh hour it is still determined to get this piece of legislation through the Senate.

This legislation is not without its defects, but there is one point I want to make. Many people have said that this legislation will help just the wealthy. This is not so. Imputation is a very important incentive to buy shares for those taxpayers on lower than the maximum tax rate. Take for example the taxpayer with a marginal tax rate of 30 per cent. In effect if he or she buys shares, those dividends will have a rebate at that rate of 49 per cent-the rate of taxation for public companies-when the individual may be paying only a 30 per cent marginal rate of tax. This is a very powerful incentive for those on a lower income tax rate to buy shares and so reduce their overall taxation commitments. One of the minor anomalies-perhaps not minor, but it was alluded to by previous speakers-that I am concerned about is that this legislation will, in effect, increase the Medicare levy on those taxpayers who are in the top tax bracket. The reason for this is fairly complicated. That is something that this legislation, which purports to overcome double taxation, should not be allowed to affect.

All in all, this country has been subjected to the iniquity of double taxation on dividends for a long time. It has been talked about since the post-war years and so far no government has been prepared to attack this anomaly simply because most governments, I believe, have been concerned only with maximising the tax take. This short-sightedness has had the effect of shrinking the capital base in this country alarmingly. Less than 10 per cent of the capital in our public companies is now in the hands of private shareholders. That is a very disturbing figure. Many Australians have no real interest in and no concern about how our major companies perform. They have no stake in their prosperity. They sit back and see the takeover merchants make large fortunes on the stock market. The average Australian has been discouraged from investing simply because he has been subjected to a 78.4 per cent tax on dividends from public companies. Happily, we will see some substantial and fundamental changes as a result of this legislation-one positive step forward in the Government's taxation legislation. I am delighted that this legislation is set to pass the Senate in the dying hours of this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 7, proposed subsection 46c (1), definition of ``debt dividend'', subparagraph (a) (i), lines 36 and 37, leave out the subparagraph, insert the following subparagraph:
``(i) the share:
(a) in the case of a redeemable preference share-was issued after the commencing time; or
(b) in any other case-was issued after 28 November 1986;''.
(2) Page 3, clause 7, proposed subsection 46c (1), definition of ``debt dividend'', paragraphs (b) and (c), lines 4 to 20, leave out the paragraphs.
(3) Page 3, clause 7, proposed subsection 46c (1), after the definition of ``loan'', insert the following new definition:

`` `redeemable preference share' means a share issued by a company the holder of which has a right to a specified rate of dividend before ordinary shareholders receive a dividend and in relation to which there is set out in the memorandum or articles of the company provision for the redemption of the share;''.

This clause relates to the changes to be made by the Government to legislation concerning redeemable preference shares and other short term financing arrangements which constitute, in essence, debt rather than equity. As stated on page 8 of the explanatory memorandum, the purpose of clause 7, which inserts a new section 46c into the Income Tax Assessment Act, is to implement the proposal announced on 7 April 1986 by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in a Press release to treat as debt, for income tax purposes, shorter term redeemable preference shares. The Committee will recall that this Bill was debated in the Senate in March and on 19 March the Senate referred the Bill to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for report on the following matters: Firstly, whether the provisions of the Bill relating to short term redeemable preference shares extend beyond the terms of the Treasurer's announcement of 7 April 1986; secondly, whether any parties relying on the clear wording of the Treasurer's 7 April 1986 announcement will find their legal rights retrospectively affected by the passage of the Bill in its present form; thirdly, the form of amendment, if any, necessary for the Bill to conform to the limits of the Treasurer's announcement; and, fourthly, whether the provisions relating to quarterly payment of provisional tax will be unduly onerous on provisional taxpayers whose income is subject to fluctuations throughout the course of a year and, if so, whether the amendment of the Bill to provide the election of payment of provisional tax in full at 31 March can achieve relief for those taxpayers only.

This amendment to clause 7 relates to the first three of the four terms of reference. The Finance and Government Operations Committee reported to the Senate a couple of weeks ago on this matter. It was a divided report; the majority, which was achieved due to the casting vote of the Chairman, concluded that the Bill did not involve retrospectivity whereas the other Committee members found that the Bill went beyond the terms set out in the Treasurer's original announcement of 7 April 1986. You, Mr Chairman, will recall that there was a gap of almost eight months between the Treasurer's announcement of 7 April 1986 in relation to the income tax treatment of redeemable preference shares and the introduction of the Bill in late November 1986.

The Opposition supports the minority view of the Finance and Government Operations Committee that the Bill as drafted goes beyond what was announced by the Treasurer on 7 April 1986 in two respects. First, in the Opposition's view, the Treasurer's 7 April Press announcement quite clearly related to redeemable preference shares, and redeemable preference shares only, whereas the Bill that was introduced eight months later refers to redeemable preference shares and other short term financing arrangements. The Bill has effect from the date of the Treasurer's Press release-7 April-so the Opposition believes that the part of the Bill covering redeemable preference shares and other financing short term arrangements is, quite clearly, retrospective.

The other area where the Bill, in the view of the Opposition, differs from the Treasurer's original announcement is that on 7 April the Treasurer said that the amendments would apply to redeemable preference shares and any other redeemable shares issued-issued being the key word-after 7 April. The Bill, on the other hand, applies to certain redeemable preference shares and other short term financing arrangements issued before 7 April, so in that respect we believe that the Bill has retrospective application. Because of its retrospectivity, we oppose this clause very strongly indeed. We do not oppose the objective that the Government is seeking to achieve in relation to redeemable preference shares and short term financing arrangements, and I stress that at the outset; what we disagree with is the retrospective application in the two instances to which I have referred.

The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations took evidence on this matter from the Australian Taxation Office and a range of companies, particularly leading taxation and accounting firms, that had been concerned, as we are concerned, with the retrospective elements. I will refer briefly to some of the issues that came up in that context. First, the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, in a letter to the Chairman of the Finance and Government Operations Committee on 14 April, attached the Australian Taxation Office's submission to the Senate inquiry and said that the Taxation Office concluded that it was only on a literalist view that it could be said that the proposed amendments extended beyond the terms of the announcement. He also said that even in that case parties would have to have deliberately chosen after the announcement to seek to exploit what they saw as a loophole. The taxation officers in giving evidence to the Committee engaged in discussion that was very helpful indeed on the question of whether or not the legislation was retrospective. During that dialogue between Committee members and the taxation officers, Mr Nolan, the Second Commissioner of Taxation, responded to a question from me. In effect, I asked: `Are you really running the risk, by having a Press statement released eight months before legislation is announced, of quite unequivocally introducing what in effect is retrospective legislation if the application of the Bill is to go back to the date of the original announcement? I would have thought that was unequivocally retrospective legislation? Would you have any comment on that?' In response, Mr Nolan said:

I think we could have, with the benefit of hindsight, recommended some tightening of the announcement, which would have overcome this difficulty. To the extent that the announcement was not as precise in its terms as the legislation is there has to be acknowledged that there is a degree of retrospectivity. Whether one is offended by that in the particular circumstances is a matter of judgment. There is an element of retrospectivity.

The Second Commissioner of Taxation in evidence to the Committee was refreshingly frank and entirely proper in stating his view, and that view was that this legislation contains an element of retrospectivity. Therefore, the evidence of a very senior officer of the Taxation Office supports the point we are making-that the Bill contains an element of retrospectivity, which applies in the two ways we have suggested.

The amendment I have circulated seeks to remove that element of retrospectivity in two ways. It deletes from the Bill any application of the Bill to shares issued before 7 April 1986 in accordance with the quite explicit wording of the Treasurer's Press release of 7 April 1986. The second effect is to remove from the application of the Bill between 7 April 1986 and the date of introduction of the Bill-28 November-short term financing arrangements other than redeemable preference shares, because short term financing arrangements other than redeemable preference shares were not referred to in the Treasurer's Press release of 7 April 1986. Indeed, the Press release was specifically headed `Redeemable preference shares, income tax treatment'. It is perfectly clear that that was the content and purpose of the Treasurer's statement of 7 April 1986.

On previous occasions we have referred in both Houses to the very disturbing trend that we have seen in recent years of governments introducing legislation in effect by Press release months and months before the actual legislation is introduced and the problems that always arise from that. That always runs the risk of the sort of thing that has occurred in this instance happening. The Opposition is absolutely, totally and adamantly opposed to any form of retrospectivity, particularly in relation to taxation legislation. If people are to go about their business in a reasonable, commercial or other manner they have to know what the law is. For legislation to be introduced which goes beyond the original announcement by the Government is total anathema to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I have some sympathy with what Senator Short is trying to do I believe that he has gone beyond the concern that I expressed during the second reading debate. It seems to me that the effect of the Liberals' amendment would be that the legislation would not have any effect prior to 28 November, even with regard to transactions that were mentioned by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Press statement of 7 April-or whenever it was. My concern and that of many people is not simply that Treasurers and others are attempting to legislate by Press release but that, having made a statement about changes that the Government intended to make to the law, the legislation amending the principal Act when finally introduced goes beyond what was signalled in the original Press release.

SPEECH.PARA: Legislation that follows precisely what was signalled in the Press release would not of itself be a problem, particularly in the tax area where it often takes quite a number of months for the complex legislation that is required to close off a loophole or to correct an unintended consequence to be drafted and to appear before Parliament. —I wish to pick up a point that Senator Haines has made, as I may not have explained myself very clearly or Senator Haines may have misread our amendment. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a complex issue and before replying specifically I think that I should give some background. The legislation seeks to close off from 6 April-the date of the announcement-a tax avoidance practice. The matter is rather complicated but, basically, companies which had unequal tax liabilities worked out arrangements under which a company, instead of lending money to another company, that is, a company that was fully taxable, would take out redeemable preference shares or some other short term financial arrangement. Because of the operation of the section 46 rebate-that is, that money flowing as dividends from one company will not be taxed again in the hands of the company receiving the dividends-the company which was notionally buying redeemable preference shares would accept a rate of interest probably at anything above 8.1 per cent, and receive the same after tax return. There was of course a consequential loss to revenue. In practice what happened was that those companies which collaborated in devising such shonky arrangements pocketed the money that they had robbed from all other taxpayers. Let there be no mistake about it. This was a dishonest device to defraud the revenue and to take advantage of loopholes in taxation law so that both companies or partners to the arrangement got a financial advantage, at the expense of Consolidated Revenue and all honest taxpayers. It was a clear abuse of section 46 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party proposes to close off from 6 April-and it has this in common with the Government-such dishonest financing arrangements which defraud the Commonwealth of revenue only if they are called redeemable preference shares. If they are called something else, so far as the Opposition is concerned, there can be open slather-for raids on Commonwealth revenue.The rationale or excuse for doing this is that the Press release of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) did not explicitly mention anything other than redeemable preference shares. If the Opposition's amendment were carried, any shonky financier who set up an arrangement at any time between 6 April and 28 November, which had exactly the same effect but which was called something other than redeemable preference shares, could get away with it, could grab the money from public revenue and run away with it. If that principle were accepted it would mean that in future if any preference arrangement was less than exhaustive in listing the scope of its application and anything less than completely watertight in its wording, it would be open season for any shonky accountant or tax lawyer to devise a mechanism which would facilitate the continued robbing of honest taxpayers of revenue, as was the case in relation to the previous arrangement. If I may say so for the record, I am not at all impressed by tax lawyers and accountants coming along to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and putting in a special plea on behalf of people who do that sort of thing. One of the problems with this country is that far too many shonky tax accountants and tax lawyers have been engaged for more than a decade in grossly anti-social activity of that type. The professions have a great deal to answer for.

It is a long established principle that measures to close off loopholes or the exploitation of loopholes in the taxation law-loopholes, incidentally, which have often been opened up by the High Court of Australia, but I leave that aside-become operative from the date of announcement.
