TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill are Bills which regularly come before the Senate for cost supplementation each year. They relate to schools funding, higher education funding and a participation and equity program. The Opposition will not oppose these three Bills, but will move a second reading amendment in regard to the schools supplementation Bill, to protect non-government schools from the intrusions of this Government and, in the Committee stage, will seek to amend those parts of the Bill that will restrict non-government schools in the provision of housing or other residential accommodation for teaching or other staff and will seek to remove from the Bill the Labor Government's restriction that no moneys be spent by non-government schools to provide facilities for use wholly or partly for religious worship.

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to these amendments, to which I will come in due course, naturally we support the moneys allocated in this legislation because those moneys will go to schools both government and non-government. The schedules of these increases are set out in the Bills. In summary, they total $106m, being $78m for tertiary institutions, $1m for the participation and equity program and $18m for schools supplementation this year, with $9m foreshadowed for 1988.

Schools are of vital importance in debates in this chamber, and indeed to Australian families. Parents care directly about the education that their children will receive because they count it to be the most valuable acquisition of children outside the family itself. That is so strongly the contention of the Liberal Party of Australia that its schools policy in this current election context is not to reduce any provisions for schools but to enable choice to be exercised freely by parents so that they may ensure that their children receive the education that they desire.

At the moment just more than a quarter of Australia's school children are attending non-government schools and 73 per cent are attending government schools. The supplementation that we have before us ensures that 100 per cent of the cost of a government school place is provided by the taxpayer, mostly through the States using Commonwealth untied grants and their other income. So state school places are fully provided by the taxpayer. In respect of non-government schools there is an enormous impediment, and that is that the parents themselves provide more than $1 billion towards the cost of school provision. This imbalance, this burden, that is placed upon the parents of students in non-government schools, we believe needs to be eased and not made heavier by the intrusions of this Government.

There has been debate not only in the Senate but also increasingly amongst parent bodies in the States and Territories to see some fairness, some equity, in the distribution of taxpayers' moneys for those schools. All parents, or at least the great majority, are citizens who meet fully the taxation laws of this country. Those who have incomes are making taxation contributions that then go on to be spent in schools. Those without taxable incomes, whether on a pension or some other benefit, are in a very small minority. We believe that it is fair and equitable that there be proper recognition that all taxpayers should be fairly and equitably assisted in the education of their children. This contrast between the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party approach to the funding of schools will be a major aspect of the current election campaign. However, insofar as the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill is concerned we have no opposition to the additional moneys being granted according to the schedules that are set out. It will adjust the levels of funding that were put in place three years ago as a four-year funding program for schools.

In respect of that four-year funding program I wish to refer to the unfortunate misleading of the Senate by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) at Question Time on Friday. I referred to this at the conclusion of Question Time today. The Minister, conscious that three-quarters of those children who are enrolled in non-government schools are attending Catholic systemic schools, wished to claim a trophy, a commendation, a direct endorsement, by the body that is responsible for policy in those schools. She cited a letter which she had received and which acknowledged only that the Government had met the request of the National Catholic Education Commission not to cut funding to Catholic systemic schools in the last mini-Budget.

There was a great deal of speculation prior to mid-May as to what the Treasurer, Mr Keating, would be cutting in his bid to cut Government expenditure. Representations were made to the Liberal Party and the Government, including representations from the National Catholic Education Commission, that schools should not be in the front line of those expenditure cuts. I agree with that, and that is why the Liberal Party will not be making any cuts to expenditure on any schools in Australia, government or non-government. When the pressure from parents, the National Catholic Education Commission and the Opposition was taken into account, happily the Cabinet decided not to cut expenditure on any of the National Catholic Education Commission schools.

When the Chairman of that Commission, Sir Bernard Callinan, wrote to the Minister on 19 May to pass on to her a copy of the most recent publication of that Commission's schools policy he directly acknowledged that there had not been cuts in schools funding and that indeed their representations had been successful. The Minister disgracefully referred to that letter in the Senate last Friday by saying this:
. . . the four-year funding scheme is one of the proudest achievements of our Government.
That is the legislation which is subject to this amending Bill. Senator Ryan continued:
I should emphasise that the National Catholic Education Commission appreciates and commends our commitment to that scheme and it has welcomed and endorsed our policies.

Both claims are nonsense. The letter does not say that. As any parent in any parents and friends association around Australia will know, the Catholic schools and indeed all non-government schools are directly critical of the apparatus that the present Labor Government has placed in the way of the expansion of non-government schools. There is a cry at every annual meeting of parents and friends and responsible administrators of non-government schools to remove the present Labor Government's intrusion into those schools. The claim of the Minister flies in the face of those hundreds and thousands of school and parents meetings around the country. When the Minister was picked up on this she was very embarrassed but failed to acknowledge that she has misled us. I make that point-I made it after Question Time today-to emphasise that there is not confidence amongst the schools of Australia in this Government's policy towards them.

The principal new feature of the amending legislation is to institute a new block funding authority in each of the States and each sector concerning non-government schools. The Liberal Party does not see that this move is, in any way, necessary; neither is it convinced that the Government knows what it is doing or that it has a practical administration plan in mind for implementing it. As is well known in the Senate, this year $55m is made available for capital distribution to non-government schools; $155m is available for government schools in addition to that available to them from State revenue. That $55m is disbursed to the various States. There are advisory committees in the States broadly representative of all non-government schools and their ranking of the applications for capital grants is put together by the advisory committees and their recommendations come before the Minister. It is rare for the Minister to disagree with the priority rankings of the advisory committees. This mechanism is working and I have yet to hear any criticism of that procedure. Certainly in the second reading speech in the other place, and in the incorporated speeches in this chamber, there is no reference to any practical advantage flowing from legislation now before us to set up block funding authorities instead of these advisory committees.

The Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts investigated, in a public hearing, what the Government intended to do. As was set out by my Liberal colleague in the House of Representatives Dr David Watson, the honourable member for Forde, witnesses for the Government lacked clarity as to how the block funding authorities would work and how moneys would be distributed between them. It is yet to be accepted by the Senate that this is a practical or beneficial move for schools. In addition, extra costs will fall on the funding authorities and they will be restricted in administering the disbursement of these capital moneys. To cover that, the Government has allowed for 2 per cent of the capital moneys disbursed up to a maximum of $35,000. As proposed, some block funding authorities will have very considerable administration costs and I directly criticise the inadequate provision of moneys. It will fall to those block funding authorities to make up the difference and so additional burdens will be placed on the peak non-government authorities.

The Liberal Party's second criticism is that a new liability will fall upon block funding authorities for the recovery of any capital disbursements that flow to a school that closes down or that does not adequately and properly use the capital moneys for the purpose for which they have been granted. In the past this has been a matter between the Commonwealth Government-the funding body-and the various schools that receive the money. However, under these new arrangements the Commonwealth Government is passing the buck to the block funding authorities which will be legally required to account for the capital moneys disbursed.

As is also well known in the Senate, any capital moneys disbursed to a school are deemed to have passed in equity from the Commonwealth to the school over a 20-year period. There is a 5 per cent growth per year in the amount of capital grant retained by the school that has received that capital allocation. If, after 10 years, a school that has received a capital grant were to close down, half of the capital that had been granted is the property of the school and half is refundable to the Commonwealth. That is a fair and well-established rule. The new aspect is that the block funding authority will be liable for the recovery of half of the money in the event that I have described. We believe that this amendment setting up block funding authorities is not practical, has not been explained in terms of completed administrative arrangements and it is further intrusive upon schools. It is also intrusive upon the state schools but not in the same way because the moneys intended for state schools will be going, as they have in the past and as they do now, directly to State government and administered through the departments of education and the States.

The Liberal Party has a completely refreshing approach to schools funding in Australia. In the coming election campaign it will be very clear that it will not be lumbering non-government school authorities, or State governments for that matter, with additional bureaucracy nor will it be requiring the excessive accountability requirements that have flowed from the Connors report on Planning and Funding Policies for New Non-Government Schools. The Liberal Party wishes to see simple accountability-that is, accountability for the grant actually received through the Commonwealth-from all who receive Commonwealth grants, whether recurrent or capital, in the education area. They should give an account as to how that money has been spent and ensure that it is spent for the purposes for which it was granted. We will not be inquiring into the resources of a school, the additional funds and assets of a school, the fee levels, of a school and the paraphernalia of excessive intrusion that this Government has set up. In great contrast with the present Government we will be providing recurrent grants in respect of every enrolment in a non-government school. Over the last four years this principle has slipped away. If a school's extension or growth is not approved by the Commonwealth Government, any additional numbers do not currently receive any support at all from the Commonwealth. Similarly, new school that does not receive the very limited scope for approval that this Government has allowed does not receive any recurrent support. We will ensure that to enable parents to choose the type of education they wish their children to have, there will be recurrent grant in respect of every enrolment in a registered school.

I now turn to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. As I have said, it is straightforward in giving supplementary moneys of $78m in the normal way according to adjustments to the schedules. Having this Bill before us gives us the chance to note the horrendous picture that lies before higher education if this Government continues in office after 11 July. It is clear from the May mini-Budget that for universities and colleges of advanced education next year there will be a $12m cut in education funding, and the year after a cut of $25m. The position is worse in technical and further education. All families with a member in a TAFE course should be warned that the cuts in TAFE announced in the mini-Budget are even worse that for higher education. Some $30m is cut out from its budget next year and the figure will be $45m the year after. This will lead directly to a reduction in student numbers in our universities, colleges of advanced education, institutes of technology and TAFE colleges.

By contrast, the Liberal Party's education policies, which were clearly announced months ago, are a program for growth in TAFE, universities and colleges of advanced education. We wish to utilise the established educational institutions so that there are the same number of free places as there are now. We wish to ensure the award of higher education scholarships and TAFE student grants so that there is the same number attending these institutions; that is, we wish to ensure all post-school education to the same extent as it is now. But, in addition, we shall return full autonomy to our universities and colleges to map out their own destiny and to set their own future by enrolling anyone at all in addition to those with free places or scholarships on whatever terms those institutions may determine. There is a great opportunity not only to enrol those who have been turned away from institutions of higher learning, but also to tap a huge number of mature age people, particularly those aged 25 to 40, who are seeking to enrol in higher education institutions.

The Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Committee of Principals and Directors in Colleges of Advanced Education published eight days ago their assessment of the unmet demand in Australia in 1987. Enrolments for March have all been completed and the statistics have all been gathered. Their finding was that by the policies of this Government there is a 22 per cent increase in unmet demand in higher education this year compared to last; 13,000 to 20,000 applying students have been turned away from our universities and colleges this year. Some 44,000 persons were turned away, their applications for enrolment having been turned down. Because some of those 44,000 people have applied for more than one course, there has been an adjustment from the gross unmet demand to a net 13,000 to 20,000. That is equivalent to more than two universities. This is a disgraceful state of affairs and the present policies of the Labor Government have no way of dealing with it. The Labor Government has frozen the administration charge, it has denied any growth in student numbers and it has banned any private resources coming in to our universities and colleges. So given the cuts of the May mini-Budget, there is no other way out of the corner into which the Government has painted itself. In contrast, the Liberal Party will ensure the same number of free places, but will also ensure that a large part of the solution to the unmet demand will be achieved by allowing full autonomy to universities and colleges to enrol as they wish.

In talking of student numbers, I wish to correct a claim that the Australian Labor Party has been making in the House of Representatives and in this place for some weeks. The claim is that in the first four years of the Labor Government there was an increase of 40,000 in student numbers, and in the last four years of the Fraser Government, Labor claims-and it is wrong-there was an increase of only 8,000. That is a comparison of 5:1 that Labor thinks it can chortle to all Australians. But when the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, uses those figures, or indeed any Minister in this Government-and the Minister for Education used them in Question Time on Friday-they are wrong. I set out carefully, in the debate on the Appropriation legislation last Thursday evening, for about an hour in this chamber a number of matters, including this one, which is now clearly on public record. Let me state unequivocally that in the first three years of the Liberal Government led by Prime Minister Fraser the figures tabled by the Department of Education in the Senate to which I referred last Thursday show an increase of 26,800, and in the first three years of the present Government the increase was 32,900. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the chamber. The table demonstrates that we have reached a plateau. If we are to depend entirely on public money for the ability to enrol students in higher education, we shall be stuck on that plateau. The contrast in this chamber is that Labor Senators have no policy change to offer but are locked into the plateau of no growth. We in the Liberal Party have an innovating return of autonomy to universities and colleges to accept the free places as they are now, but to enrol additional students on whatever terms they see fit.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I come to the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill. An additional $1m has been set aside for that program. What is clear is that the Government's rhetoric about participation and equity is so inflated that the balloon has now burst. The facts are that this is the last year of the program; this final topping up is the last time we shall see anything in relation to participation and equity. Those concerned were so disillusioned with the program's lack of success last year that they halved the money in 1986 to give half of it for the year 1987. The recent report of the Schools Commission `In the National Interest' found:
It is difficult to establish a direct causal relationship between the activities which PEP has fostered and the rising levels of retention in secondary schools.

This is the end of PEP, and it goes not with a bang but with a whimper. It has been an ineffective publicity exercise by this Government that has failed. We now see before us the final reference to it in amending legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987 and the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill 1987. I intend to make special reference to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987, the purpose of which is to adjust and supplement tertiary education grants to the States and the Northern Territory, taking account of the cost increases.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to use this debate to raise some matters relating to the lack of places at tertiary institutions throughout Australia. A great deal of debate is taking place in the community about the lack of places in universities and colleges, especially for young people who have just completed their secondary school education. Unwarranted attacks have been made on the Hawke Government, falsely accusing it of being to blame for the current situation. There is no evidence that the Hawke Government has been niggardly in its funding of the tertiary education sector. The opposite is the case. The Government's commitment to education, given the difficult economic conditions which prevail, is highly commendable. Certainly, the Minister for Education, Senator Susan Ryan, has every reason to be pleased that under her stewardship of the education portfolio far more tertiary education places have been created than in any comparable time by the previous Government.

Of special significance to the State of Queensland, which I represent, is the fact that the Hawke Government has discriminated in favour of Queensland with funding for higher education. This has been necessary because Queensland lagged so far behind the other States when the Hawke Government was first elected in 1983. The poor state of post-secondary education in Queensland is a direct result of previous conservative governments' neglect. When tertiary funding was a responsibility of the States, successive Queensland Country Party-Liberal Party governments afforded tertiary education a very low priority. As a result, Queensland lagged behind other States in the opportunities it provided for young people in that State. After the Com- monwealth assumed responsibility for tertiary funding-an initiative of a former Labor government-the Fraser Government's funding policies exacerbated the unsatisfactory legacy of previous conservative governments. The Hawke Government recognised that additional funds were urgently required in Queensland and set about to provide young people in that State with the same opportunities as their interstate counterparts.

It would be folly to suggest that the unsatisfactory situation in Queensland could be rectified overnight. If it could, I would be delighted. It would mean that thousands of young people, who could not secure a place at a university or college, would have the opportunity to further their studies. Yet, although there are no instant solutions, under the current Government Queensland has received a greater proportion of funding for higher education than it would have received, had funding been allocated on a strict per capita basis. Let us look at the figures associated with the funding of higher education in Queensland. Nationally, 36,800 extra higher education places have been provided since 1983. Within that national growth rate of 14 per cent, Queensland's share is 22 per cent. The 22 per cent increase in places compares extremely favourably with Queensland's population share of 16 per cent. In addition to this positive discrimination, this year's funding provides for the establishment of a Gold Coast College of Advanced Education.

I would like to examine some of the other achievements in higher education under the Hawke Labor Government. Labor took office in 1983. Since that year tertiary education funding has increased by almost 8 per cent in real terms. That contrasts with the abysmal record of the Fraser Government. In the last four year of that Government, tertiary funding actually declined by 0.6 of 1 per cent. How can the Opposition criticise the Hawke Government's record when it has significantly increased funding of the tertiary sector and when its predecessor, the Fraser Government, actually presided over a decline in funding? The community does not generally recognise how much the Commonwealth spends on education. In this calendar year the Hawke Labor Government is spending $2,383m or $2.383 billion on higher education alone. When we take account of all of its other commitments we find that the outlay is about $5 billion. These are significant amounts which are sometimes overlooked when the record of the Government is being examined. These funds have provided increased educational opportunities for post- secondary students. I will be happy to look at the figures which the previous speaker, Senator Teague, incorporated in Hansard. I must admit that I did not see them before they were incorporated, but I will have a look at them later. However, I do not think that my figures are incorrect.

As I mentioned earlier, the Hawke Government has increased the number of higher education places by 36,800. This is an increase of 14 per cent. This figure of 36,800 contrasts with a growth of 8,000 places in the last four years of the Fraser Government. There are now 400,000 students in higher education-an increase of 54,000 since 1983. No matter which way the figures are examined, they highlight the Labor Government's commitment to the tertiary sector of education.

This Government not only has been interested in expanding the provision of educational opportunities but also has been interested and successful in increasing equity in participation in higher education. The greatest growth has occurred in outer metropolitan areas where there are large concentrations of lower socio-economic and other disadvantaged groups. Participation by women in education has increased substantially, with female enrolments in advanced education exceeding those for males for the first time. Aboriginal student participation in the higher education courses has increased from 700 students in 1983 to 1,500 in 1986. The Government expects a further increase of 20 per cent this year. It is one thing to provide opportunities for education. It is another to provide opportunities in areas consistent with the needs of the Australian economy. The Hawke Government has been mindful of its responsibility in this area and has thus fostered increased links between higher education institutions and industry. Business funding of chairs, co-operative projects and the activities of the commercial sectors of institutions have all increased. To assist in this area, the Government has established an industry liaison unit in Senator Ryan's portfolio.

I referred earlier to the lack of places in tertiary institutions and made special reference to the situation in Queensland. I outlined measures that this Government had taken and is still taking to provide more places at tertiary institutions. At this stage, I would like to mention some of the consequences of a shortage of places at tertiary institutions. As well as creating problems for post-secondary students, the lack of tertiary places has an effect on students at secondary school. They study under the continual pressure of knowing that every test they complete is vital for their chances of going to a college or university. Neither is the lack of places conducive to the mental health of parents who know that their son or daughter is competing against every other student in the same year for the opportunity to carry on their studies beyond the year 12 level. These problems are present now, but this Government has not pushed them to one side. Rather, it has taken initiatives to make more educational opportunities available and to make the educational system more relevant. Young people clearly welcome these initiatives. The Government's efforts have borne fruit. In 1986 there were about 130,000 more people under the age of 25 in the post-compulsory education than in 1983. This was an increase of 16 per cent in just three years.

The Hawke Government's approach to higher education funding has produced highly satisfying results. The task of rebuilding our tertiary sector after the years of Fraser neglect must continue. This Government has the will to continue the task. At the forthcoming election the people of Australia will acknowledge the fact that the Hawke Government has runs on the board. On the other hand, the higher education policy of the Opposition does not address the problem of providing tertiary places for young Australians in an acceptable way. It makes no commitment to increase funding. It undertakes to retain the number of publicly-funded places at the level of those now available; that is, about 390,000. An immediate consequence of this policy would be that there would be 5,000 fewer places available for first-year students.

The Opposition's only answer to the shortage of places is to allow those who do not gain entry on their merit to buy a place. The only potential students who would be advantaged by this scheme are the wealthy or those who have wealthy parents. It is interesting to examine the cost of the Opposition's scheme for those students who have to buy a place at university or college. Let us consider a course in medicine. It is not unreasonable to expect that tuition fees for a course in medicine would be about $16,000 a year. That would have to be paid each year for six years. That is almost $100,000 for a start, without even considering living and accommodation expenses. Not all courses are as expensive as that, but they would still be far too costly for most Australians. A course in engineering would cost around $60,000 to $70,000 in fees alone and the fees for a full law course would be about $30,000. To this would have to be added living expenses. The reality is that only the extremely wealthy could afford this option.

Under the Opposition's policy, all the good work that the Hawke Government has done at the secondary school level to increase participation would be dashed when young people tried to gain entry to higher education. This buy yourself a place scheme is no answer to the problems we are facing with higher education. In the coming weeks, the people of Australia will see that the Opposition is as bereft of realistic policies in this aspect of education as it is in many other areas. It is worthwhile examining the way in which the Opposition intends to administer its free places system. The Opposition intends to create some sort of voucher system for students who qualify for the free places. This is a badly thought out policy. The vast majority of students would try to cash in their vouchers at the larger, more established universities. This would assume that these institutions have an almost infinite capacity to expand. Of course, they do not, but we could initially expect them to grow quite substantially in student numbers. Meanwhile, under this Opposition policy, what would happen to the smaller and less established universities or colleges? They would begin to wither away. Their student numbers would drop and so too as a consequence would their staff numbers decline. This would not occur immediately, but it certainly would be a medium term result. In the long term, the outcome would restrict student choice because there would be a smaller number of institutions to which students could choose to go.

How would a system of national scholarships be administered? There is a tremendous diversity in the various secondary systems throughout Australia. Each system has its own form of final year assessment. Putting a national assessment system into place would be an administrative nightmare. Would the Opposition force the states to adopt a particular form of assessment, or would the States simply be by-passed? What would the costs of the Opposition's policy be? We do not know presumably because the Opposition itself does not know. I could go on and comment further on the Opposition's ill thought out policy on higher education, but what I have said is sufficient to indicate that it is a policy which should be rejected by the Australian people. This Opposition had the opportunity in seven years of government to develop and improve tertiary education.

TALK.START.PARA: —It did nothing.

—I take that comment, because it is ever so true. It failed to do so then and it is therefore comforting to know that the Opposition's policies will, due to the electors of this country, not be put into place.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I reiterate that we do have a problem in providing places at the tertiary level. It is regrettable that this problem exists, but the Hawke Government has tackled this problem with vigor and with realistic policies. It will continue to do so. It is of particular importance to the people I represent that the Government will continue to discriminate in favour of Queensland until the provision of tertiary education in that State is equal to that of the other States of the Commonwealth. The Government is to be congratulated on its commitment in this area, and so too is the Minister for Education, Senator Susan Ryan. The Opposition's policy is no answer for potential higher education students throughout Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill give the Senate an opportunity to look at the state of education in Australia in 1987. Given the forthcoming election, we need to look at the nature of Commonwealth responsibility for education. The central issue of the election is how Australia should best adjust in a period of economic change, education should be a crucial aspect of this debate. The dramatic decline in Australia's terms of trade and the very high level of foreign debt have made it clear that there must be far reaching structural change to the Australian economy. The recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development survey of Australia stressed that we must shift the nation's resources to brain-based industries. In this way we can replace our reliance on primary industries for export income and enable our imports to be replaced by Australian-made goods.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government believes that its policy of lowering protective barriers, allowing the dollar to devalue and providing tax concessions for private research and development spending will drive this reallocation of resources. Furthermore, the Government has contracted Budget outlays severely, based on the belief that this will dampen consumption and hence imports. It is also hoped that this will stimulate business investment in these new areas through a decline in public demand in loan markets. It is also hoped, of course, that interest rates will fall as a consequence. The trouble with this strategy is that it does not gell with the Government's education strategy. This Government, in looking at education expenditure, has treated it as part of the economic problem and not part of the economic solution.

Devaluation and lower protection will not of themselves lead to more export-oriented and import-replacement brain-based industries. Appropriate human skills must also be developed. Therefore as a society we must invest more in our people. We must rely more than ever before on the quality of the Australian people and endeavour to improve that quality. The necessary investment in people will not come from the private sector. Indeed, the private sector has yet to fulfil the Government's expectations of increased investment in physical plant and equipment. At the same time as we were told last week of the Government's intention to call an election, we learnt that business investment in plant and equipment had fallen by 9.8 per cent in the March quarter. The necessary investment in people will come only through public expenditure.

Given that the Commonwealth Government has the responsibility for the overall management of the Australian economy, the onus as far as investment in education is concerned rests with the Commonwealth. The Federal Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, told a conference in Melbourne recently that reform of the Australian education system was urgent and would make or break the economic development and living standards of Australia. Yet in the Government's May economic statement we find that it actually proposes to reduce expenditure on higher education and research in the coming two financial years. Amongst other things, general recurrent grants for higher education are to be reduced by $12m in 1987-88, if this Government is re-elected, and $24m in 1988-89. Those two items-a thrust on the part of the Government through its industry policy to base itself on brain based industries while at the same time depriving our citizens of the ability to partake, as employees and directors within those industries-do not go together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you agree that you have to take into account the universities' incomes from outside sources, particularly resulting from the taxation incentives?

—I take that point but I have just said that this funding will not be replaced by private investment. In fact, private investment, even in such things as plant and equipment, as I have already pointed out, dropped by 9.8 per cent in the March quarter.

SPEECH.PARA: Supposedly, the Government suggests higher education institutions can absorb these particular cuts through increased efficiencies. I would like to know how they will be able to do this, given that last year's review of efficiency and effectiveness in higher education by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission found that, through a decade of increased economies by the higher education system, there were hardly any significant areas for further cuts. Indeed, to quote the phrase used, there was `limited scope for additional savings'. That report makes it fairly obvious that the types of savings that would be available in that area are meagre pickings indeed-certainly nothing of the level by which the Government has chosen to cut education. At the same time, this report points out that advances made by the sector in that decade, in terms of large growth of student numbers and increased research, especially through contract research from private and other public bodies, were an important factor in the growth of Australia and Australian industries. The fact is that we have got a lot from the higher education machine. What it needs now is more oil. It is not a matter of building a new machine, as those who suggest the privatisation of public institutions are arguing at present. Doubtless during this election campaign these people will be arguing this with more noise and heat than quality argument.

This year the Government achieved some growth in student places in higher education through the use of part-I stress, only part-of the revenue from the administration charge. Some 3,000 extra places have been created this year at a cost of about $18m. Considering that the effect of the across the board flat tax on students was to bring in $50m, that is a meagre amount indeed. Given the proposed cuts in the recurrent grants and the pipeline effect of this year's increased intakes, how does the Government, if it is re-elected, propose to increase intakes to meet at least some of the unmet demand for higher education places? This year between 13,000 and 20,000 people who qualified to enter higher education could not find places, according to the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals in Advanced Education.

What is the answer, then, to this problem of unmet demand? The Liberal Party of Australia proposes that public expenditure be held at existing levels-depending on other budgetary considerations-and that students be given the right to buy full fee places if they do not gain entry to publicly funded places. This will help the thick and the rich, no doubt, but it will certainly not help others. The most likely result would be those people finishing up with tremendous loans. Going down that particular track of loans and debt would take us into the ambit of the sorry state of the United States education system at present. As I pointed out last year, and as I had reaffirmed to me this year when I was in Washington two weeks ago, student dependence on loans in the United States has caused an incredible drop in the proportion of people from disadvantaged groups who are able to enter higher education. Those who have in fact gone into higher education are being saddled with debts which last for decades. In fact, the operation in the United States is now being called the negative dowry effect. Higher education students tend to be older than they are in Australia. They tend to marry and compound their debts and tend to find that other costs associated with marriage, such as children and houses, all have to be postponed. Those people who enter higher education are faced with this spiralling effect, and this situation has many people in the United States extraordinarily worried about where their entire system is going.

The Government's answer to these types of problems, of course, has been to move towards fees. Two years ago the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) went to the Labor Caucus to stop the efforts of some of her Cabinet colleagues to reintroduce fees. But, of course, she was fighting a losing battle. The implementation this year of the $250 administration fee is a sign of what is to come. I believe this Government is moving inexorably down the line of fees probably of the order of $5,000 within the next three years. I think it is inexorable, looking at all of the factors on the Government's agenda at the moment.

The Government's monitoring committee on the impact of the charge has shown how flawed this particular scheme is. Despite the Government's efforts, disadvantaged groups, such as women financially dependent on their husbands, suffered through the charge; and the administration of the fee has been costly for institutions. The financial benefit to them of the fee is thereby significantly reduced. The message from this particular experiment with the administration fee should be clear: Fees are neither an equitable nor a financially efficient way of expanding higher education in this country. Of course, as Senator Teague claimed in a speech he made earlier, the Liberal Party was looking to giving a greater autonomy to higher education institutions through different financial arrangements. This particular claim can certainly be challenged on the basis of the likely effect of the Liberal Party's other proposal, to have a standardised test scheme as a way of allocating government scholarships to students. Such a national assessment scheme would require a return to a very narrow and very standardised curriculum, or an aptitude test similar to the Public Service entrance exam on which to judge students. Difficulties of examining and marking on a national basis would make it impossible for flexibility in accrediting students for higher education courses. Such a scheme would cut across the autonomy of higher education institutions to determine entrance criteria.

Advances in senior secondary education in recent times have been achieved because universities and colleges of advanced education have been more flexible in determining entry criteria and criteria for success in higher education. A standardised testing scheme such as that proposed by the Liberal Party Opposition would in fact destroy these advances, not enhance them. The Australian Democrats are opposed to limiting the autonomy of higher education institutions with those types of standardised operations, as we are opposed to the Government's propositions with regard to fees. We believe that we need to take the 1977 funding base for higher education and fund education at least on that basis. If we did, undoubtedly public expenditure would have to rise, and that unmet demand would be satisfied through that operation. We advocate increased public expenditure on economic grounds alone, because it does not make sense not to make this particular investment if we are serious about allocating society's resources in such a way that more emphasis is placed on brain based industries. Certainly we should encourage supplementary private funding of higher education through partnership research and development, consultancies and bequests. Such funding is also a means of implementing technology transfer which we have available to us. But this funding should not be an excuse to reduce public funding of higher education further. One way of helping to guarantee this would be having the Government fund the sector on a long term basis, as it decided to do for the private schooling sector in the Bills it introduced in 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, in a discussion of the States grants Bills, I raised some issues with regard to the state of education in Australia today. I referred to the need to encourage supplementary private funding of higher education through partnership research and development, consultancies and bequests and, of course, it is a means of technology transfer to industry and to commerce in Australia. However, this funding should not be used as an excuse to further reduce public funding of higher education. I pointed out also that one way of helping to guarantee this would be for the Government to fund the higher education sector on a long term basis as it decided to do for the private schooling sector in 1985. Furthermore, there should be safeguards against short term activity geared to private sector needs undermining academic freedom and the role of higher education to provide long term curiosity-motivated research. Earlier this year I was appalled when the Liberal Party Waste Watch Committee questioned the worth of this latter sort of research when it examined the annual report of the approved grants of the Australian research grants scheme. It is worth recalling that the transistor and biotechnology are products of earlier so-called esoteric research.

SPEECH.PARA: When we talk about the role of education in training to underpin economic development, I believe that it is necessary to stress the role of the technical and further education sector, a sector which is the joint responsibility of the Commonwealth and State governments. Too often, TAFE is forgotten in the education debate in this country. Schools attract attention because they concern families with young children; families and parents who are involved in their schools on a day to day basis along with the hopes that they have for their children. Universities and colleges of advanced education have on their side the prestige of professional education and fundamental research to advance their cause in society, but if we wish to restructure our economy, then the Commonwealth must provide more resources for technical and further education. This is especially so in the light of the May economic statement. If re-elected, the Government proposes that in the coming two financial years there would be a $200m reduction in general purpose payments to the States. This is in addition to stricter limits on borrowings by State governments and their statutory bodies. The ability of State governments therefore to devote the necessary increase in resources to TAFE must be in question and, when one considers that education as a percentage of State Budgets ranges between 25 per cent and 40 per cent, obviously the education sector in the State Budgets must be seen to be under threat.

Perhaps of all the education sectors it is the TAFE sector that can respond most quickly to problems of shortages of needed skills in the work force and TAFE can be an effective means of giving opportunity to those people made vulnerable by economic and technological change. In this respect I am thinking of those young people who have left school at 15 or 16 years of age and who will be looking but, unfortunately, unable to find work, particularly in traditional areas of unskilled labour. There are many cases where these people need to be able to develop their skills through on the job experience. If they leave school and look for jobs, they are more likely to find dole queues. Also, I am thinking of new immigrants to this country and of those mature age workers who find their existing skills made redundant by technological change. These changes are necessary for the economy, but they are at a cost which should be spread throughout society and not borne by single individuals. All of these groups must have the chance to train or to retrain if they are to maintain their identity and self-respect.

Through TAFE we can achieve a mass tertiary education sector. In recent years there has been remarkable growth in the TAFE sector. In the period from 1974 to 1984 TAFE enrolments in vocational and preparatory courses almost doubled from 458,000 to 831,000, which was an enrolment one and a half times as great as that of other parts of the higher education sector. Consistent with changes in the economy and the youth labour market, TAFE full time enrolments increased from some 38,000 in 1976 to 80,000 in 1984. No longer can we associate TAFE education with on-the-run night school training, yet the ability of the TAFE sector to meet the enrolment demand is even more constrained than that of the higher education sector. So I find it hard to swallow the logic of the Government's May economic statement which talks about the need for emphasis on training rather than the valium of short term job creation. The Australian Democrats agree with that philosophy, but the Government then proposes to cut the community employment program by $300m. It then plans to spend only $93m extra on training programs and that is after reducing general grants to States by $30m for TAFE purposes. If we recall the state of education five years ago, this problem of unmet demand for tertiary education is somewhat ironic. At that time we lamented the fact that the proportion of school leavers entering higher education had actually fallen, as argued in the 1982 Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission report `Learning and Earning'. We were worried also about the poor retention rates in our schools as well as growing youth unemployment. That was five years ago. Now we find that the retention rates have improved dramatically. In 1982 the retention rate in Government schools to year 12 was 29.6 per cent. By 1985 that figure had risen to 40 per cent. While youth unemployment rates as a percentage of the youth labour market are still high-some 20-odd per cent-the actual size of that youth labour market has contracted as more young people have remained in education and in training. In absolute numbers, youth unemployment has decreased.

In the light of these changes the Commonwealth has a moral obligation, as well as an economic imperative, to provide the necessary extra resources to higher education and technical and further education to meet unmet demand. If the Commonwealth does not do this-and to date it shows no inclination to do so-we will find that the pressures on the tertiary sector also will warp school education. There will be a race for credentials because, without them, a young person will have no future. Young people will undergo enormous stress in cramming for exams and the necessary school results for entry to tertiary education. As a result, we may find social problems in the form of youth suicides and mental breakdowns, not unlike that which takes place in the very highly competitive Japanese school education system. Wealthy parents will do all that they can to advantage their children in such an inhumane system. More parents will perceive that a private school education and not a government school education is a better start for the education race. This will lead to growing tensions between government and non-government schools, but such a situation hardly will be in the interests of the community as a whole.

I believe that all this actually does flow from the Government's current position of trying to hold two incompatible policies with regard to young people. In contrast, the Democrats believe that the Commonwealth should bring about greater harmony between the sectors. It should use its funding powers as a means of bringing about a greater sharing of resources between the private and the state government school sectors along with a common approach to planning. Unless we solve this problem of unmet demand for post-secondary and tertiary education, we will find that schools will scramble over each other in the race to give their students better credentials for tertiary education entrance.

I have argued strongly about the economic importance of education expenditure by the Commonwealth. But we must always put this in a larger context. Education is also about individuals, self-discovery and growth. Education provides a foundation for a democratic society. A passive electorate is too easily manipulated. Education must provide access to a shared cultural and intellectual heritage if it is to bind its citizens together into a Commonwealth. For these reasons, the extreme economic rationalists must not be allowed to capture policy makers. As eminent Australian historian, Sir Keith Hancock, says in his autobiography Country and Calling: `Life is a good deal more than its tasks, and training is only a part of education'. In looking at the wider structure, it is also interesting to note the following quotation from Tawney:

Few tricks of the unsophisticated intellect are more curious than the naive psychology of the businessman, who ascribes his achievements to his own unaided efforts, in blind unconsciousness of a social order without whose support and vigilant protection he would be as lamb bleating in the desert.

The role that education has to play is, in fact, to structure the broader society in which the economy is but a part. But this Government has treated education as part of the problem. When times are tough-and it is accepted that economic times are tough-I believe it can be argued, and argued cogently, that the last place to cut is in education. I have already quoted from a speech that Senator Button made not so long ago in talking about the role of education in the development of industry in Australia. I believe that what he had to say in that speech was correct but, unfortunately, the education policy of this Government runs in the opposite direction. We do need those skills for our citizens, but providing for those skills is a job for government. It will not be taken up by the private sector, which wishes to use the results of the education system, never acknowledges the usefulness of the education system but emphasises its failings, and never points to the fact that the education system underpins and provides it with the wherewithal to take from the general pool those creative, intelligent and useful individuals who provide the backbone of industry and the professionals and who provide industry and commerce with their greatest resource.

An efficient education system is one which maximises the productive potential of the work force and gives that productivity a joint rather than an individual concept. As Davidson said in a very useful article recently, education can only maximise the community productive potential by providing an education which maximises the potential of all its citizens. I believe that we are facing a period in Australia's education debate that will move away from a discussion about what is the right school for pupils to attend-is it a private or a state school?-and will move to a debate about the role of education in general and the contribution it can make. We should welcome such a debate and, hopefully, in this election campaign the debate will be focused on that type of role. If that occurs, the simplistic notions that education, somehow, is only for the private good and not for the public good could easily be dispelled. It is necessary that we move forwards in this area and not backwards.

The higher education sector is currently the most vulnerable sector in terms of government policy making and is likely to remain so during the period of the next Parliament whoever wins the next election and forms the next government. What we are looking at is continuing pressure on higher education institutions to provide more and more with less and less. That will not be possible and ultimately it will be seen that by starving our higher education institutions of funds in terms of both their teaching function and their research function we have done a massive disservice to Australia and its citizens for generations to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three States grants Bills now before the Senate are machinery in nature and principally seek to grant additional funds for adjustments in cost escalations in tertiary educational institutions, schools and the participation and equity program. The National Party of Australia does not wish to oppose these Bills, understanding that such supplementation is necessary from time to time because of this country's high inflation rate brought about by this Government, although we are willing to support the second reading amendment that has been moved by Senator Teague on behalf of the Opposition. I will say from the outset that the larger issue of the usurping of the States' role in education by the Commonwealth Government is cause for concern. I will address that issue later.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of these Bills, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987, provides $78m for retrospective supplementation in the areas of recurrent costs, capital and equipment expenditure and academics' salaries in accordance with increases granted by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. University academics' salaries, however, are not included in this round of legislation because they have a somewhat fanciful claim for a 100 per cent increase before the Commission.

The second of these Bills, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1987, amends the principal Act primarily to supplement grants to Government and non-government schools in 1987 and 1988 in accordance with the recent national wage case and with the general increase of price levels. The other major provisions of this Bill is to alter the method of allocating capital grant funds to non-government schools. Since this Government came to office this is the third major alteration in the method of allocating these funds. The latest arrangements provide for capital grants funds to be paid as block grants to approved authorities in each State. These block grant authorities will be responsible for recommending the funding priorities of their member schools to the Minister and later distributing moneys to these member schools.

It is anticipated that two major blocks will be established in each State under the stewardship of the Catholic Education Commission and the Association of Independent Schools in each State. Any school not wishing to participate in a block authority will have the option of joining the national pool and applying to the Minister directly for capital funds. The National Party has no argument with the concept of this sort of decentralisation and minimisation of bureaucracy.

Significant practical difficulties, however, arise from the proposed implementation of this program, and it is far from certain that any bureaucracy will be minimised. Although in principle this is a sensible program, the administrative guidelines proposed by the Minister are burdensome. The accountability requirements, as drafted, appear to be overly demanding, time consuming and full of anomalies. For instance, annual and quarterly reporting is required, however funds will be advanced to the block grant authorities in 11 equal instalments each year. It would seem more practical to coincide the reporting periods with the funding periods.

In effect, the block grant authorities will be responsible for the initial administrative filtering of applications for capital funds. Any real decisions relating to the allocation of funds will be made by the Minister and determined according to strict criteria established by the Minister. The guidelines are unclear as to the level of involvement of the Department of Education and to what extent, if any, individual authorities will be able to make decisions in respect of determining funding priorities. Once individual projects have been approved by the Minister, funds will be able to be distributed by the block authorities. Because block grant authorities are required to have corporate status, they will also have all the legal obligations associated with such status. The legal position of the block grant authorities in relation to the Commonwealth's equity in school capital projects is problematical.

Under the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1984, the Commonwealth retains equity in any project funded by the Federal Government for 20 years, reducing at the rate of 5 per cent per year. Should any member school breach its agreement in respect of using a facility for its agreed purpose-for instance, if a school relocates or closes as a result of a rationalisation program-the block grant authority involved is liable for refunding to the Commonwealth the value of the outstanding equity. I suggest that this should be a matter between the particular school and the Commonwealth. Bodies such as the Catholic Education Commission and the Association of Independent Schools do not have the mechanisms and certainly do not have the funds to pursue legal action against member schools on behalf of the Commonwealth should such a situation arise. Certainly, the Commonwealth must ensure that the public interest is being protected, but the Minister's intention of vesting the block grant authorities with the Commonwealth's debt collecting role is an unreasonable expectation to place on such authorities.

The block grant authority program completely bypasses the State education departments in relation to any input in the area of allocation of capital grant funds to non-government schools. Education is an area into which the Federal Government has systematically insinuated itself over the past two decades, with the current Labor Government being particularly active in this regard. Under the Constitution, responsibility for education rests with the States, except in relation to the Territories and student benefits. Section 96 empowers the Commonwealth to provide financial assistance to the States on such terms and conditions as determined by the Parliament.

By virtue of the fact that the Commonwealth provides funds for education, the Minister has progressively assumed a more significant role in the direction and formulation of education policy, perhaps at the expense of the States. The establishment of the block grant authority program is yet another example of the erosion of States' rights. There exists no logical justification for the Commonwealth overseeing such a scheme and duplicating resources when the appropriate mechanism exists in each State.

The National Party of Australia firmly supports the right of individuals to freedom of choice in education and supports the rights of parents to choose a form of schooling consistent with their beliefs and values. Indeed, there is no doubt that schools are of vital importance to all Australian families. Parents care about the education that their children will receive. I listened to Senator Teague telling us that 73 per cent of children attend government schools, while slightly more than 25 per cent attend non-government schools. However, the parents of the children who attend those non-government schools have to provide money to help meet the cost of their children's education, and that amounts to probably more than $1 billion.

Many parents choose to send their children to non-government schools so as to provide them with a Christian education. Given that a significant number of parents choose this option for their children, I believe that this confers upon the Government a responsibility to maintain the non-government education sector. From 1974 to 1983 the growth of the non-government school sector was enormous. During this period primary enrolments in non-government schools increased by 11 per cent, while those in government schools declined by 3 per cent. In the secondary school area, non-government enrolments increased by a massive 29 per cent, compared with an increase of 8 per cent in government schools. It is of great concern to me that the non-government sector may be in jeopardy in the long term should the Commonwealth continue to intrude into the operation of these schools. We must support non-government schools, and I contend that the protection of their long term existence can best be provided by returning administration of this sector to the States.

The third Bill before the Senate today is the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill 1987. Again, this Bill seeks to provide retrospective cost supplementation for the participation and equity program. The PEP was established for the purpose of increasing participation rates in education beyond the compulsory years of schooling. Further, the program sought to address the problems of inequality of access to education for various disadvantaged sub-population groups. It is interesting to note that the Government has credited PEP with having made great advances in increasing retention rates. However, an examination of the figures cannot support this claim. The most substantial movements in retention rates occurred in 1983 and 1984.

The participation and equity program was introduced in 1984 and that year was largely devoted to planning the actual programs and establishing the necessary administrative machinery. It was not until 1985 that the program became fully operational. I believe that the marked increase in retention rates in 1983 and 1984 was a response to the unprecedented increase in teenage unemployment. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that unemployment rates for 15-to 19-year-olds rose from 13.1 per cent in 1981 to 21.8 per cent in 1983. I do not dispute that the long term solution to the problem of teenage unemployment is for our youth to spend longer periods in education and to develop the type of skills that will assist them to gain employment. The participation and equity program is due to finish at the end of 1987. I suggest that the replacement program be designed to be more effective and less costly. It is interesting to note that Queensland has the highest student retention rate of any State-57.5 per cent, as compared to 44 per cent in New South Wales and 46.8 per cent in Victoria, and is well above the national average of 48.7 per cent.

We all realise the vital role that education plays in the lives of all Australians, particularly our young Australians. The Government must do everything possible to assist the State governments with the necessary finance to ensure a continuation of good educational standards at all levels. As I said earlier, the National Party does not really oppose the passage of these Bills, although we support the amendment that has been moved by Senator Teague on behalf of the Opposition, namely, that, at the end of the motion for the second reading, the following words be added:

. . . with the exception of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987, and that this Bill be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for the removal of constraints imposed on non-government schools, or on non-government school communities, which will in any way destroy their independence and opportunities for expansion or interfere with the special character of non-government schools.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. There were some constructive contributions. I suppose it is always welcome when we are discussing education matters and education funding, although there are disagreements about amounts and principles of allocation, that at least there is agreement that education is an enormously important area for the Commonwealth Government to be involved in and an enormously important area for the community. Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who has just resumed her seat, at least endorsed the policy that our Government has been pursuing with outstanding success for four years now, of providing more and more young people with greater opportunities to continue their education and training.

SPEECH.PARA: We have achieved this success by a number of means. It would be tempting to use the debate on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987, States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill tonight as an opportunity for us to rehearse our campaign speeches. Some honourable senators have probably already yielded to that temptation. However, I will not do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—Senator Michael Macklin I am sure will have the opportunity to hear me on the campaign trail. Senator Macklin is very well aware, being a senator who takes a great deal of interest in education, of the enormous achievements of the Labor Government over the last four years. He is very well aware of the enormous increases in participation by students to the end of year 12. He would know that much of that increase has occurred in disadvantaged schools in disadvantaged areas. Schools in advantaged areas already had a very high participation rate. It was the schools in the poorer areas, government schools and also non-government schools serving poorer areas, which had desperately low rates of retention to the end of year 12 and which are now showing a much healthier picture.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin will also be aware, because one of the pieces of legislation we are discussing is the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill, of the improvements and increases there have been in higher education. There has been rapid enrolment growth. Over 40,000 more students are now enrolled in our universities and colleges of advanced education than were enrolled when we took office. We have a much better level of student assistance. Every level of student assistance has been increased under the Hawke Government, which has enhanced the possibilities for students from poorer families or from struggling average families to take advantage of the 40,000 extra places we have created in our universities and colleges. Senator Macklin will be aware of other initiatives too, but as I said I will resist the temptation to make my campaign speech on this legislation tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —When consideration in Committee of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) was interrupted before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I think most of what needed to be said about clause 7 had been said. I had moved on behalf of the Opposition an amendment to clause 7 to remove what the Opposition sees as the retrospective elements of the Bill. In the Opposition's view there are two retrospective elements, which follow from the fact that the original proposals for the legislation were set out in a Press release of 7 April 1986 and the legislation was introduced at the end of November 1986. In the opinion of the Opposition, and as stated in a minority report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, the Bill contains retrospectivity in two respects. The original statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) referred to the proposed Bill as relating to redeemable preference shares issued after 7 April 1986. The Bill allows in certain circumstances for its application to shares issued before that date, so that is one element of retrospectivity.

SPEECH.PARA: The second element of retrospectivity occurs because, while the Treasurer's Press statement referred only to redeemable preference shares, the Bill, which emanated eight months later, refers to redeemable preference shares and other forms of short term financing arrangements. The Opposition's amendment attempts to remove both retrospective elements, first by amending clause 7 to remove from it the application of the Bill to redeemable preference shares issued before 7 April 1986; and, secondly, to remove from the application of the Bill financing arrangements other than redeemable preference shares between 7 April 1986 and the date of introduction of the Bill, namely 28 November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments moved by Senator Short on behalf of the Opposition take into account not only the retrospective element relating to redeemable preference shares but also the possible retrospective application to other short term financing arrangements. We have had considerable contact with legal and accounting firms which have been concerned about elements of this legislation, but we have not been given any examples of other possible short term financing arrangements which may have been put into operation between April and November and which may well have been jeopardised by this legislation; that is, picked up retrospectively as being inoperable. SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, we are concerned about the part of the case put forward by Senator Short and the Opposition relating to redeemable preference shares, but we cannot support the Opposition's amendments on the grounds that between 7 April and 28 November there may have been an arrangement, system proposal or whatever relating to some other short term financing arrangements put into operation which is likely to be affected retrospectively by this legislation. While I can sympathise with the concern of Senator Short and the Opposition that this legislation does not pick up retrospectively anything other than that which was specifically mentioned in the statement of 7 April, we do not believe that it is wise to go as far as this amendments seeks to go. I do not want to take up the time of the chamber discussing our amendment as I shall get around to that if this amendment is defeated and we move ours. Suffice it to say, what we intend to move satisfies part of the concern of Senator Short and the Opposition but does not go as far as picking up all possible, probable, likely or hypothetical short term financing arrangements in a blanket amendment.

By way of explanation I think it might be useful if I run through the instructions that we gave to the parliamentary counsel when we sought their assistance in drafting this amendment. We put five items to the parliamentary counsel with regard to having them draft this amendment. The first criterion was that the legislation be amended so that it not apply where the relevant shares were issued prior to the commencing time and where the only act subsequently undertaken was a mere extension of previously existing arrangements. However, we sought provision for the amendment to the legislation to not exclude other new short term finance arrangements entered into after the commencing time, and that it also apply to all substituted arrangements entered into after the commencement time. The second criterion that we put to the parliamentary counsel was that the legislation not apply where a person, after the date of announcement, has paid calls on partly paid shares issued prior to the commencing time. However, it was necessary to ensure that the legislation still apply whether or not shares were changed in character since the date of announcement. So that was a rider to the second criterion.

The third criterion was that the legislation not apply where, after the commencement time, a person has taken no action other than that required under a legally binding contractural arrangement entered into prior to the announcement. The fourth criterion was that the legislation not apply where there has been a transfer of shares after the commencing time but where there has been no alteration to the rights attaching to the shares or the value. An example of such a transaction would be where a company holding short term preference shares transferred the shares to a subsidiary or holding company after the date of the announcement. Finally, we put in the requirement that the legislation not apply where shares have been issued prior to the announcement under legally binding arrangements but there has been an amendment of those arrangements after the commencing time, provided that any change to the Bill did not, firstly extend the time during which the arrangements operate; secondly, increase the amount of money to which such arrangements apply; or, thirdly extend the operation of the arrangements to shares other than shares first issued prior to the commencing time.

In putting those criteria to the parliamentary counsel I believe we satisfied the concerns raised with us by a number of organisations regarding an element of retrospectivity that they perceived. It certainly ensured that the concern raised by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, among other groups and individuals, that legislation by Press release was getting out of hand. Our action acknowledged that concern and sought to ensure that to the best of everybody's ability the legislation applied only to the elements indicated in the announcement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating); that is, to redeemable preference shares. So we believe the amendments satisfy stated concerns regarding retro- spectivity. Having had the amendments drafted, my office got in contact with a number of the agencies which had contacted us and put to them, not just over the phone but by facsimile, what the proposed amendments were and sought their comments. Those groups indicated that they were satisfied that the concerns they had raised on this legislation had been picked up by these amendments and they had no further complaints. On those grounds, I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 13, clause 16, after proposed new subsection 221yba (1), insert the following new subsections:
