The amendment proposes the addition of the abovementioned proposed new sub-sections to the proposed new sub-section 221yba (1). The three sub-clauses would have the effect of enabling provisional income taxpayers to elect whether they wish to pay their provisional tax under the Government's new proposed quarterly instalment arrangements or to remain with the existing system of a once-only payment towards the end of the year. It will be said by the Government, I am sure, that this amendment would have the effect of negating the proposal that the Government has put in relation to the quarterly payment of provisional tax. It is certainly not intended to do so. Rather it is intended to give more flexibility to provisional taxpayers whose payment arrangements, and therefore the desirability of their paying at different times of the year, will vary considerably. There may well be taxpayers who, for reasons of continuity, reliability and stability of cash flow, would in fact prefer to pay their provisional tax on a quarterly basis as is being proposed by the Government. On the other hand, there are taxpayers, particularly those with unusual and unpredictable seasonality in their incomes from one year to another and from one time of the year to another, for whom it is very difficult to pay on a quarterly basis as proposed by the Government.

I appreciate that the Bill contains provisions to allow for some flexibility in terms of payment on other than a quarterly basis. Nevertheless, in the Opposition's view, that does not go far enough. For that reason, I have moved this amendment. I understand that the amendment moved by the Opposition will not have the support of the Australian Democrats and will therefore be lost. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a number of reasons the Australian Democrats will not support the amendment moved by Senator Short on behalf of the Opposition. With regard to provisional income tax, one of the reasons for the change to the legislation was to introduce a greater equity for pay as you earn taxpayers who have no choice but to have their tax payments deducted at source fortnightly or monthly, according to when they are paid, but nevertheless having the deductions made on a regular basis throughout the financial year. Therefore, it was something of an inequity that a number of people were able to pay provisional tax on an annual basis and were able to have full use of the money in the meantime. The passage of Senator Short's amendment moved on behalf of the Opposition I think would have meant introducing a fairly massive inequity between PAYE taxpayers and other income earners, including some very high income earners who have the capacity to make use of that money for the extra 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I do not think that there is a great deal of point in closing off one inequit- able situation in order to open another. In this case, I think that two groups of people need to be considered. One of those groups includes people whose income fluctuates quite significantly during the year or between the years, seasonally or for any other reason. The other group includes people in small business-and I mean small business and not larger businesses that hope to get away with being called small businesses by belonging to some association that includes the term `small business' in its name, when in fact the business is not small at all. In any event, I refer to genuine small businesses that simply cannot cope with the additional administration costs and that are too small to have accountants and smart lawyers to help them. We intend to oppose Senator Short's amendment, because I think that it only opens up a larger inequity than that which currently exists by allowing everybody total freedom to opt either for quarterly or for annual payments, in which case those who are likely to benefit from an annual payment will opt for that method and will get around what the Government is trying to do in closing the inequity. In that case we will certainly oppose the amendment, but we will move our own amendments that will pick up people who suffer from the problems associated with fluctuating incomes. At the moment, I will not discuss those amendments because I think that it is more appropriate that we deal with them when we come to them, but one such amendment relates to clause 16, following the defeat of this amendment to clause 16, and the other relates to an amendment to clause 20, which simply lifts the ceiling on a group of people who the Government has acknowledged already would be disadvantaged if the legislation with regard to quarterly or annual payments were not amended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Short did not claim this but, because it has been claimed before, I think it is worthwhile putting the record straight: Under the existing arrangements provisional taxpayers are advantaged over pay as you earn taxpayers, that is, wage and salary earner taxpayers, in two ways. First, if their incomes are constant, they pay their tax liabilities on average three months later than do PAYE taxpayers, but if their incomes are not constant, and that is a more common situation, they have the additional advantage that, in a year where the taxable income for the year on which the provisional taxation is levied, and that becomes payable at the end of March, is above the provisional tax assessment, which is necessarily based on the taxable income in the previous year, sometimes with some minor adjustment, the taxpayer is under no obligation to notify the Commissioner for Taxation that the taxable income for the year for which the provisional tax is being levied will be higher than the income which the Australian Taxation Office had assumed. With that obligation falling due on 31 March that means that the provisional tax, on average, is paid three months later. However, if the taxable income for the year on which the provisional tax is levied is less than that for the previous year and upon which necessarily the Taxation Office had based the provisional taxation assessment, the taxpayer has the option to vary that provisional tax liability downwards; in other words, it is an option that is stacked in favour of the taxpayer, with no corresponding penalty.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the existing arrangements, the provisional taxpayer is advantaged over PAYE taxpayers in two ways. The Government Bill proposes that provisional taxpayers be liable to pay tax on a quarterly basis, thereby making it a little more equitable when compared with PAYE taxpayers. Therefore, the measure relates to equity, as well as other matters. As Senator Short mentioned, there are provisions for special circumstances and specifically this has some relevance to one of the foreshadowed amendments. I refer to those people who derive more than 75 per cent of their income from primary production being allowed to pay twice yearly instead of quarterly; in other words, to pay on 1 February and on 1 June, which leaves them in very much the same position in which provisional taxpayers are now, so it is an equity measure.

There is an additional reason why the Opposition's amendment should not be accepted. The Opposition amendment effectively makes the payment of quarterly provisional tax optional; in other words, it virtually emasculates this provision of the Bill. This Bill amends the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986 to implement the decision announced in the Treasurer's statement on 13 May to introduce a system of quarterly instalments for the payment of the Commonwealth's general purpose assistance for local government. This amendment will apply with effect from 1987-88. A system of quarterly instalments will enable the Commonwealth to better match outlays and receipts resulting in a saving in public debt interest payments due to a reduced financing task within each year. As the Treasurer indicated in his statement on 13 May, a sustainable recovery in Australia's economic fortunes requires governments at all levels to exercise restraint.

The introduction of a system of quarterly payments to local Government complements the decisions to cut back on the Commonwealth's own purpose outlays and the decisions taken at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meetings on 25 May 1987 to cut back the Commonwealth's general purpose payments to the States. Under the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986, the amount of general purpose assistance in 1987-88 will be escalated in line with the change in consumer price index in the year to the March quarter 1988 over the previous year. Previously, the Commonwealth has made a payment, usually during September, to each of the States and the Northern Territory, for distribution to local governing bodies of their estimated annual entitlements, that is, a single lump sum early in the financial year.

The amendment provided for in this Bill will mean, so far as practicable, that annual entitlements will be paid in equal quarterly instalments. The Government proposes to make these payments no later than the fifteenth of August, November, February and May respectively. It will not be possible, however, to make a quarterly payment by mid-August in 1987. This payment will be made at the same time as in previous years, that is, normally before the end of September. The new arrangements will mean that from 1988-89, the first payment to local Government will occur at least four weeks earlier than had previously been the case. The changes in this Bill will not affect the amount being provided to local government under the Act, but there will be some loss of benefit to local Government, principally as a result of interest revenue foregone. CUSTOMS TARIFF VALIDATION BILL 1987

The Customs Tariff Validation Bill 1987 provides for the validation until the thirty-first of December 1987 of duties collected in pursuance of Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 10, 11 and 12 (1987) which were introduced into the House of Representatives on the seventh of May 1987, and Customs Tariff Proposals No. 13 (1987), and Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Proposals No. 1 (1987) which were introduced on the twenty-ninth of May 1987.

Under section 226 of the Customs Act 1901 the collection of duties in pursuance of customs tariff proposals is protected against legal challenge for twelve months or until the close of the session of Parliament, whichever occurs first. The introduction and passage of a validation Bill is therefore a necessary machinery measure to protect the collection of the duties which have been introduced by the proposals.

The tariff changes contained in the customs tariff proposals arise from: the Government's decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on luggage and vegetables and vegetable products; the granting of duty free entry to gas barbecues and parts therefor of New Zealand origin; the variation in customs duty rates on imported petroleum products to align with changes in the excise duty on equivalent locally produced goods.

The change contained in the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Proposals corrects an unintended situation where certain blends of coal currently being marketed as steaming coal were being subject to an export duty.
Financial Impact
Because the validation of the changes contained in the proposals merely continues their application, the Bill has no financial impact as such.
I commend the Bill.
EXCISE TARIFF VALIDATION BILL 1987

The Excise Tariff Validation Bill 1987 provides for the validation until the thirty-first of December 1987 of duties collected in pursuance of Excise Tariff Proposals No. 6 (1987) which were introduced into the House of Representatives on the twenty-ninth of May 1987.

Under section 114 of the Excise Act 1901 the collection of duties in pursuance of excise tariff proposals is protected against legal challenge for twelve months or until the close of the session of Parliament, whichever occurs first.
The introduction and passage of a validation Bill is therefore a necessary machinery measure to protect the collection of the duties which have been introduced by the proposals.
Financial Impact

The changes contained in the excise tariff proposals increased the duties on locally produced petroleum products because of a fall in the price of indigenous crude oil under the Government's import parity pricing policy. The change in the levels of excise was designed to offset the changes in revenue from crude oil excise and royalty.
I commend the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the Government's attention an urgent matter concerning the International Whaling Commission's moratorium on all commercial whaling until a full review has been completed of whale population assessment and whale management methods. The International Whaling Commission is currently reviewing the scientific issues involved so that it can determine how to estimate the number of whales which can be caught without endangering the whale stocks world wide. The Japanese Government has adopted a subterfuge to continue commercial whaling, despite this moratorium. This subterfuge involves issuing permits to enable the Japanese whaling fleet ships to kill 3,300 minke whales and 200 sperm whales, over a period of four years, for ostensibly scientific purposes. This action will make a mockery of the moratorium decision of the International Whaling Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unilateral declaration by the Japanese Government that it will undertake research on its own terms, using its own fleet and, of course, making use of the whales that it catches for its own commercial ends. It claims that the aim of this study is to estimate the natural mortality of whales to help solve the management problem. However, there is considerable doubt that its sampling method will provide sufficiently accurate information on natural mortality to be of use in determining maximum catch levels. In order to provide useful estimates of natural mortality one would require a considerably larger sample, of tens of thousands of whales. This, of course, is more than the existing whale populations could possibly withstand world wide. Already many hundreds of thousands of whales have been killed, and the data collected has not solved the management problem.

The proposed method has been analysed by a Dr W. K. de la Mare, a member of the Scientific Committee of the International Whaling Commission. He points out the wrong assumptions made by the Japanese in their proposals for scientific research: Firstly, that the population's study will remain constant over four years; and, secondly, that the sampling will have a negligible contribution on the mortality levels of a cohort of whales. But neither of these propositions can be justified, particularly in view of the stress on whale populations which is already evident. I believe that this point is very important in bringing this matter to the notice of our Government. Other factors will also introduce sufficient bias into the experiment, so that the results will be of no practical use to anyone, and it becomes just a sacrificial exercise in the name of science-a sacrifice to the god of commercialism, profit and greed.

In contrast to the attitude of the Japanese Government, I draw to the attention of the Senate the recent decision by the Soviet Government to recall its whaling fleet from Antarctic waters. The Soviet Government is to be congratulated on its decision to recall that fleet. There now seems no reason for its continuing its objection to the moratorium on whaling. I hope that it will join us in putting pressure on Japan, Iceland and South Korea which are ostensibly the only nations now continuing to pursue the whaling industry.

It is extremely important that our Government should immediately enter into discussions with the Japanese Government, the Korean Government and the Icelandic Government to try to stop the slaughter of whales in our Antarctic waters, which is taking place for very wrong reasons. It is completely hypocritical to suggest that the killing of whales by Japan will in any way benefit the whale population world wide. I ask the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) whether the Government will make representations to the governments of Japan, Korea and Iceland to support the International Whaling Commission moratorium on all commercial whaling and to forbid such a mockery of that moratorium under the guise of scientific research. I have given Senator Ryan notice of this matter, and I hope she has managed to obtain some answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In concluding the adjournment debate, I would like Senator Vigor to know that the Commonwealth Government is aware of allegations that some of the countries which have a commercial whaling tradition have sought to avoid the International Whaling Commission moratorium on commercial whaling by using the pretext of engaging in whaling for scientific research. It is expected that, pursuant to these guidelines, all proposals for scientific whaling will be scrutinised by the Scientific Committee of the International Whaling Commission. ANSWER.PARA: The figure of $775 million was the full year revenue gain for fringe benefits tax (FBT) and substantiation, as estimated at the time of the 1986-87 Budget. It was anticipated that this figure would be reached after four years of operation of the substantiation provisions. The estimate of $105 million revenue gains from substantiation, contained in the Treasurer's Statement of 19 September 1985, related to the estimated revenue for 1987-88. It is therefore not comparable to the $200 million figure mentioned above.

The amendments to the FBT and the income tax substantiation requirements, announced on 29 October 1986, reduced estimated full year revenue for the FBT and substantiation to $700 million. The estimated reduction of $75 million was spread between the FBT and substantiation categories.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 March 1987 (Hansard, page 1296) Senator Boswell asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce a question without notice concerning the relative treatment of goods purchased by independent retailers and by national chain retail stores under the wholesale sales tax. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Sales tax is payable on the value of goods at the point of last wholesale sale. The question concerns the situation where a retailer purchases taxable goods direct from a manufacturer, this sale being the relevant transaction for levying tax. The Government accepts that this design feature can advantage retailers who purchase direct from manufacturers, rather than through wholesalers and may advantage those retail chain stores which vertically integrate upstream by performing wholesale functions themselves.

In its Draft White Paper on Reform of the Australian Tax System, the Government identified this as one of the weaknesses inherent in a WST. The only certain method of eliminating the problem to which the senator refers would be to replace the WST by a retail sales tax or a VAT. However, these taxes also are not without their disadvantages.
